commit_message:
Bump up delorean pinning

We need to use a fresher delorean version to install the
openstack-dashboard

Change-Id: Icfba869a60155248932107f6badeda7f9a19384c

commit_message:
add bagpipe driver and agent

including:
- add a README-bagpipe.rst for the bagpipe driver
- add setup.cf entry points
- extend devstack plugin so that the modified agent
  can be enabled with Q_AGENT=bagpipe-openvswitch

Change-Id: I6cd18eca77e5f2b43b0b15d141637cef6db044e4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-bgpvpn refs/changes/76/171976/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: NETWORKING_BGPVPN_DIR=$DEST/networking-bgpvpn BAGPIPE_OVS_AGENT_BINARY="$NEUTRON_BIN_DIR/neutron-bagpipe-openvswitch-agent"

commit_message:
Verify that each step provisioning went well

Use the serverspec hook to verify that the previous provisioning step
left the platform in an expected and correct state. It is a dependency
to go and run the next step.

Change-Id: Ic63a62b655f3dc221c9462cb555e878d4ad8b57c
Depends-On: I8efc9a2278e972fe0c61e12823a9250a4a1bc27d
Depends-On: I56d0c8ecb2cfd1ff21b606dad010ccc2b53ebb94

commit_message:
Remove run_cross_tests.sh

This script is part of the oslotest package now.

Change-Id: Ib25f07ea71726142d1b2fd4135b2ee65c5d37d0b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.config refs/changes/71/179471/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: #!/bin/bash # # Run cross-project tests # # Usage: # # run_cross_tests.sh project_dir venv # Fail the build if any command fails set -e project_dir="$1" venv="$2" if [ -z "$project_dir" -o -z "$venv" ] then cat - <<EOF ERROR: Missing argument(s) Usage: $0 PROJECT_DIR VIRTUAL_ENV Example, run the python 2.7 tests for python-neutronclient: $0 /opt/stack/python-neutronclient py27 EOF exit 1 fi # Set up the virtualenv without running the tests (cd $project_dir && tox --notest -e $venv) tox_envbin=$project_dir/.tox/$venv/bin our_name=$(python setup.py --name) # Replace the pip-installed package with the version in our source # tree. Look to see if we are already installed before trying to # uninstall ourselves, to avoid failures from packages that do not use us # yet. if $tox_envbin/pip freeze | grep -q $our_name then $tox_envbin/pip uninstall -y $our_name fi $tox_envbin/pip install -U . # Run the tests (cd $project_dir && tox -e $venv) result=$? # The below checks are modified from # openstack-infra/config/modules/jenkins/files/slave_scripts/run-unittests.sh. # They expect to be run in the project being tested. cd $project_dir echo "Begin pip freeze output from test virtualenv:" echo "======================================================================" .tox/$venv/bin/pip freeze echo "======================================================================" # We only want to run the next check if the tool is installed, so look # for it before continuing. if [ -f /usr/local/jenkins/slave_scripts/subunit2html.py -a -d ".testrepository" ] ; then if [ -f ".testrepository/0.2" ] ; then cp .testrepository/0.2 ./subunit_log.txt elif [ -f ".testrepository/0" ] ; then .tox/$venv/bin/subunit-1to2 < .testrepository/0 > ./subunit_log.txt fi .tox/$venv/bin/python /usr/local/jenkins/slave_scripts/subunit2html.py ./subunit_log.txt testr_results.html gzip -9 ./subunit_log.txt gzip -9 ./testr_results.html export PYTHON=.tox/$venv/bin/python set -e rancount=$(.tox/$venv/bin/testr last | sed -ne 's/Ran \([0-9]\+\).*tests in.*/\1/p') if [ "$rancount" -eq "0" ] ; then echo echo "Zero tests were run. At least one test should have been run." echo "Failing this test as a result" echo exit 1 fi fi # If we make it this far, report status based on the tests that were # run. exit $result

commit_message:
Implement group related methods for LDAP backend

This patch implements three functions, empty in the LDAP backend,
which are necessary to obtain information about groups,
such as roles, projects and domains of the groups.

These are the functions:

- list_domain_ids_for_user
- list_domain_ids_for_groups

Change-Id: Ie0e2ad9b24add9e3a27a251e089e12acf36ce933
Closes-Bug: #1333712
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/27/157327/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: role_ids = [] project_subtree_dn = self.project.tree_dn for group_id in group_ids: group_dn = self.group._id_to_dn(group_id) for group_role in self.role.list_project_roles_for_group( group_dn, project_subtree_dn): role_ids.append(self.role._dn_to_id(group_role.role_dn)) return role_ids project_ids = [] for group_id in group_ids: group_dn = self.group._id_to_dn(group_id) for group_role in self.role.list_project_roles_for_group( group_dn, self.project.tree_dn): project_ids.append(self.project._dn_to_id( group_role.project_dn)) return project_ids return [CONF.identity.default_domain_id] return [CONF.identity.default_domain_id]
deleted_lines: raise exception.NotImplemented() raise exception.NotImplemented() raise exception.NotImplemented() raise exception.NotImplemented()

subject: Temporarily add trove plugin configuration
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-24 21:58:28.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack-gate/commit/11449b88f34d12ed62983093a6de402810db97dd', 'message': 'Temporarily add trove plugin configuration

In order to move the trove configuration from devstack to trove,
we need to enable the plugin.  This should be done in a job config,
but since that can not be tested with a change and will break if
it lands before the plugin is moved, enable it in devstack-gate
to facilitate the transition.

Once the transition is complete, this can be removed.

Change-Id: I3506dec0e6097f9c2e9267110fdfb768faa23c85
Depends-On: I15667bf9c063e886755aef29056ef0028cbb1080

commit_message:
Temporarily add trove plugin configuration

In order to move the trove configuration from devstack to trove,
we need to enable the plugin.  This should be done in a job config,
but since that can not be tested with a change and will break if
it lands before the plugin is moved, enable it in devstack-gate
to facilitate the transition.

Once the transition is complete, this can be removed.

Change-Id: I3506dec0e6097f9c2e9267110fdfb768faa23c85
Depends-On: I15667bf9c063e886755aef29056ef0028cbb1080

Devstack will:
* Disable the v2 API in Keystone paste config;
* Set Tempest to skip Identity v2 tests and use

'}]
commit_message:
Pass the flag for Identity v3 API only jobs

When DEVSTACK_GATE_IDENTITY_V3_ONLY is set to 1,
pass it as IDENTITY_V3_ONLY=True in the devstack
local.conf file.

Devstack will:
* Disable the v2 API in Keystone paste config;
* Set Tempest to skip Identity v2 tests and use
  v3 auth tokens to run all the other tests;
* Set Horizon to use v3 API and v3 auth tokens.

Change-Id: I345170430ced6c1443292a8f3dc3b9e6c105ee70

commit_message:
Allow overwriting sphinx builder from command line

The build_sphinx setuptools command supports selection of a builder.
Support the behaviour of being able to explicitely select any builder
available to sphinx via "python setup.py build_sphinx -b linkcheck", not
just one of the builders specified in the configuration file.

Change-Id: I4c7ddcaf413e1bcc72550b3d920f8a777a710c97

commit_message:
Enhance error message in update_machine

Updated error messages through the use of try/except blocks in
update_machine in order to help a user identify what the possible
cause of a failure could be without studying the code.

Change-Id: I04db479ce1b25aadd710cde5d90fe71fa528869b

commit_message:
incorrect SSL header used in example config

Updating the example local_settings.py to have HTTP_X_FORWARDED_PROTO in
addition to HTTP_X_FORWARDED_PROTOCOL.  Only Django 1.4 uses
HTTP_X_FORWARDED_PROTOCOL and Django 1.5 and up uses HTTP_X_FORWARDED_PROTO
which is probably the majority of installations.

Closes-bug: #1446836
Change-Id: Iebb854cf5e5586c6613b5755d4641ee896056334

commit_message:
Fix can_send_version to check against the base client version

Up until now clients would happily pass any version as long as there is
no version_cap specifed, disregarding the version of the Target that was
passed in to the constructor.

This now makes it fail if the version is higher than the one passed on
construction. A sideffect of this change is that now specifying the cap
that is higher than the version of the target passed in is that it will
always fail the can_send_version test.

Closes-bug: #1330916

Change-Id: Ic4f1b46bb331c3af9d041bc47fecf1f9bdb96871
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging refs/changes/50/97750/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

added_lines: import threading cfg.IntOpt('rabbit_heartbeat', default=5, help='seconds between rabbit keep-alive heartbeat.'), 'virtual_host': virtual_host, 'heartbeat': self.conf.rabbit_heartbeat, 'virtual_host': virtual_host, 'heartbeat': self.conf.rabbit_heartbeat, def send_heartbeat(self): self.connection.heartbeat_check() class RabbitListener(amqpdriver.AMQPListener): def poll(self, timeout=None): if timeout is not None: deadline = time.time() + timeout else: deadline = None while True: if self.incoming: return self.incoming.pop(0) try: self.conn.send_heartbeat() except Exception: self.conn.reconnect() if deadline is not None: timeout = deadline - time.time() if timeout < 0: return None try: self.conn.consume(limit=1, timeout=1) except rpc_common.Timeout: continue def listen(self, target): conn = self._get_connection(pooled=False) listener = RabbitListener(self, conn) conn.declare_topic_consumer(exchange_name=self._get_exchange(target), topic=target.topic, callback=listener) conn.declare_topic_consumer(exchange_name=self._get_exchange(target), topic='%s.%s' % (target.topic, target.server), callback=listener) conn.declare_fanout_consumer(target.topic, listener) return listener def listen_for_notifications(self, targets_and_priorities): conn = self._get_connection(pooled=False) listener = RabbitListener(self, conn) for target, priority in targets_and_priorities: conn.declare_topic_consumer( exchange_name=self._get_exchange(target), topic='%s.%s' % (target.topic, priority), callback=listener) return listener

subject: Add heartbeat support to kombu
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-07-04 08:02:01.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging/commit/95a8e44ebac19056f8d8c9f1cd475686ff5a4cdd', 'message': "Add heartbeat support to kombu

This change adds heartbeat support for kombu by passing in heartbeat parameter
of default value 60 second and adding a thread(eventlet) that spawns after heartbeat/2
seconds to check for the connection.

This is a critical bug fix for cases where network connections are not reliable.
One of my test scenario had a NAT between nova-compute and the nova-conductor/nova-scheduler.
NAT devices are known to drop idle connections without telling corresponding parties of
the state of the connection. This behavior caused interesting 'hung' operation on nova side.

Here are the details:
Setup:

Nova-Conduct/Scheduler are running on a machine 'P' along with Broker
Nova-compute C is running on a virtual machine local at my workplace behind a NAT.
Both P, C are using Kombu 3.0.16 (https://pypi.python.org/pypi/kombu)

P creates a 'topic' exchange and create a Queue (nova_compute_<id>) which needs acknowledgements.
C waits for the message upon arrival sends an ack back to B.

Scenarios:

Positive:
P and C are connected to B, P publishes messages, C receives it and everything works fine.

Negative:
While C is connected to B,

step-1) I disconnect the 'virtual network' which disconnects the virtual machine C is running on.
So effectively C is not reachable anymore. (This should be similar to unplugging network cable to a machine)

At this point of time, I observed the following on broker machine:

rabbitmqctl list_connections name state timeout : it shows the connection between the B and C as running, timeout value=0
rabbitmqctl list_queues name messages_ready messages_unacknowledged: shows name and both ready and unacked messages =0

step-2) I then publish a message from P on the Q.

Now

rabbitmqctl list_connections name state timeout : it shows the connection between the B and C as running, timeout value=0
rabbitmqctl list_queues name messages_ready messages_unacknowledged: shows name and both ready =0 and unacked messages =1

step-3) I then publish another message from P on the Q.

Now

rabbitmqctl list_connections name state timeout : it shows the connection between the B and C as running, timeout value=0
rabbitmqctl list_queues name messages_ready messages_unacknowledged: shows name and both ready =0 and unacked messages =2

step-4) I plug 'connect' the network for C again but I never see the messages on the C they remain in the unacked state > 8 hrs (I didn't check after that).

Solution:
After the fix, the timeout value in Step-1,2,3 = 60 and step-4 succeeds and the messages are delivered.

Some references:

http://kombu.readthedocs.org/en/latest/reference/kombu.connection.html
https://www.rabbitmq.com/amqp-0-9-1-reference.html
https://github.com/celery/py-amqp/

Change-Id: Iee6866890aa24f46f03daae7e7f4b5d2c99dde65

rabbitmqctl list_queues name messages_ready messages_unacknowledged: shows name and both ready =0 and unacked messages =1

Now

rabbitmqctl list_connections name state timeout : it shows the connection between the B and C as running, timeout value=0
rabbitmqctl list_queues name messages_ready messages_unacknowledged: shows name and both ready =0 and unacked messages =2

step-4) I plug 'connect' the network for C again but I never see the messages on the C they remain in the unacked state > 8 hrs (I didn't check after that).

Solution:
After the fix, the timeout value in Step-1,2,3 = 60 and step-4 succeeds and the messages are delivered.

Some references:

http://kombu.readthedocs.org/en/latest/reference/kombu.connection.html
https://www.rabbitmq.com/amqp-0-9-1-reference.html
https://github.com/celery/py-amqp/

commit_message:
Add heartbeat support to kombu

This change adds heartbeat support for kombu by passing in heartbeat parameter
of default value 60 second and adding a thread(eventlet) that spawns after heartbeat/2
seconds to check for the connection.

This is a critical bug fix for cases where network connections are not reliable.
One of my test scenario had a NAT between nova-compute and the nova-conductor/nova-scheduler.
NAT devices are known to drop idle connections without telling corresponding parties of
the state of the connection. This behavior caused interesting 'hung' operation on nova side.

Here are the details:
Setup:

Nova-Conduct/Scheduler are running on a machine 'P' along with Broker
Nova-compute C is running on a virtual machine local at my workplace behind a NAT.
Both P, C are using Kombu 3.0.16 (https://pypi.python.org/pypi/kombu)

P creates a 'topic' exchange and create a Queue (nova_compute_<id>) which needs acknowledgements.
C waits for the message upon arrival sends an ack back to B.

Scenarios:

Positive:
P and C are connected to B, P publishes messages, C receives it and everything works fine.

Negative:
While C is connected to B,

step-1) I disconnect the 'virtual network' which disconnects the virtual machine C is running on.
So effectively C is not reachable anymore. (This should be similar to unplugging network cable to a machine)

At this point of time, I observed the following on broker machine:

rabbitmqctl list_connections name state timeout : it shows the connection between the B and C as running, timeout value=0
rabbitmqctl list_queues name messages_ready messages_unacknowledged: shows name and both ready and unacked messages =0

step-2) I then publish a message from P on the Q.

Now

rabbitmqctl list_connections name state timeout : it shows the connection between the B and C as running, timeout value=0
rabbitmqctl list_queues name messages_ready messages_unacknowledged: shows name and both ready =0 and unacked messages =1

step-3) I then publish another message from P on the Q.

Now

rabbitmqctl list_connections name state timeout : it shows the connection between the B and C as running, timeout value=0
rabbitmqctl list_queues name messages_ready messages_unacknowledged: shows name and both ready =0 and unacked messages =2

step-4) I plug 'connect' the network for C again but I never see the messages on the C they remain in the unacked state > 8 hrs (I didn't check after that).

Solution:
After the fix, the timeout value in Step-1,2,3 = 60 and step-4 succeeds and the messages are delivered.

Some references:

http://kombu.readthedocs.org/en/latest/reference/kombu.connection.html
https://www.rabbitmq.com/amqp-0-9-1-reference.html
https://github.com/celery/py-amqp/

Change-Id: Iee6866890aa24f46f03daae7e7f4b5d2c99dde65
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging refs/changes/83/104783/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Support for rabbit heartbeat mechanism to check if the connection to rabbit is alive cfg.IntOpt('rabbit_heartbeat', default=60, help='seconds between rabbit keep-alive heartbeat.') # The thread that sends heartbeat self._heartbeat_thread = None self._start_heartbeat_thread() def _start_heartbeat_thread(self): if not self._heartbeat_thread: self._heartbeat_thread = eventlet.spawn(self._send_heartbeat) def _cancel_heartbeat_thread(self): if self._heartbeat_thread: self._heartbeat_thread.kill() self._heartbeat_thread = None def _send_heartbeat(self): """ Kombu supports 'heartbeat' for rabbitmq. To support that the 'Connection' object takes a 'heartbeat' parameter and in addition 'heartbeat_check' needs to be called see following for more detail http://kombu.readthedocs.org/en/latest/reference/kombu.connection.html Even though Kombu doc talks about heartbeat every second, the rabbit doc suggest that it should receive hearbeat before the heartbeat interval expires. This thread uses rabbit negotiated heartbeat /2 as the sleep interval. """ interval = self.conf.rabbit_heartbeat/2 while True: try: if self.connection and self.connection.connected: LOG.debug('Calling heartbeat_check on AMQP connection') interval = self.connection.get_heartbeat_interval()/2 self.connection.heartbeat_check() else: LOG.debug('Connection is not up, skipping heartbeat') except Exception as e: # It is not clear how the code should behave in case of error, there doesn't # seem to be a simple way of notifying existing operation and cancel them, in # worst case those operations will error out. LOG.warn('Error performing heartbeat_check ' + str(e)) time.sleep(interval) self._cancel_heartbeat_thread()

commit_message:
Trap formatting errors

Trap errors when trying to use translated messages as format strings so
translations don't break applications. Log the error, with the format
string (without interpolated values) and the original message so a bug
report can include it to make fixing the translation easier.

Change-Id: I4cd385dffc0b23c7cc6a663dd1700ac14a84c5d2
Closes-bug: #1339337

added_lines: def test_mod_with_wrong_field_type_in_trans(self): msgid = "Correct type %(arg1)s" params = {'arg1': 'test1'} with mock.patch('gettext.translation') as trans: # Set up ugettext to return the original message with the # correct format string. trans.return_value.ugettext.return_value = msgid # Build a message and give it some parameters. result = _message.Message(msgid) % params # Now set up ugettext to return the translated version of # the original message, with a bad format string. if six.PY3: trans.return_value.gettext.return_value = u'Wrong type %(arg1)d' else: trans.return_value.ugettext.return_value = u'Wrong type %(arg1)d' trans_result = result.translate() expected = msgid % params self.assertEqual(expected, trans_result) def test_mod_with_wrong_field_type(self): msgid = "Test that we handle unused args %(arg1)d" params = {'arg1': 'test1'} try: _message.Message(msgid) % params except TypeError: pass else: self.fail('Did not see TypeError for failed type conversion') def test_mod_with_missing_arg(self): msgid = "Test that we handle missing args %(arg1)s %(arg2)s" params = {'arg1': 'test1'} try: _message.Message(msgid) % params except KeyError as e: self.assertIn('arg2', six.text_type(e)) else: self.fail('Did not see a KeyError for missing param arg2')

commit_message:
Added functional test for RPC

added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import threading import uuid from oslo.config import cfg from oslo import messaging from tests import utils as test_utils class TestRPC(test_utils.BaseTestCase): def setUp(self): super(TestRPC, self).setUp() self._transport = messaging.get_transport(cfg.CONF, 'rabbit://localhost/') self._topic = 'testtopic-%s' % uuid.uuid4().hex self._target = messaging.Target(topic=self._topic, server='server1', version='1.0') self.server = self.mox.CreateMockAnything() self.server.target = None self.client = messaging.RPCClient(self._transport, self._target) self._rpc_server = messaging.get_rpc_server(self._transport, self._target, [self.server], executor='blocking') def server_thread(): self._rpc_server.start() self._rpc_server.wait() self._server_thread = threading.Thread(target=server_thread) self._server_thread.daemon = True self._server_thread.start() def tearDown(self): self._rpc_server.stop() super(TestRPC, self).tearDown() def test_basic_call(self): basic_context = {'context': 'foo'} self.server.rpc_method(basic_context, a=2, b=2).AndReturn(4) self.mox.ReplayAll() result = self.client.call(basic_context, 'rpc_method', a=2, b=2) self.assertEquals(4, result)

commit_message:
Brand new ReplyWaiter based on futures

Made reply handling code much simpler.
As a bonus overall performance of calls is doubled.

Removed one of the test cases that tested logic of previous
ReplyWaiter. Right now it's not needed since we don't have complex
conditions to care about.

New ReplyWaiter code is tested indirectly in test_impl_rabbit
test_send_receive test.

Change-Id: Ieba012e67a9857ca84cd5af4d3aed31ee09f6142
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging refs/changes/69/112669/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: from oslo.messaging._drivers import amqpdriverclass TestRacyWaitForReply(test_utils.BaseTestCase): def setUp(self): super(TestRacyWaitForReply, self).setUp() self.messaging_conf.transport_driver = 'rabbit' self.messaging_conf.in_memory = True def test_send_receive(self): transport = messaging.get_transport(self.conf) self.addCleanup(transport.cleanup) driver = transport._driver target = messaging.Target(topic='testtopic') listener = driver.listen(target) senders = [] replies = [] msgs = [] wait_conditions = [] orig_reply_waiter = amqpdriver.ReplyWaiter.wait def reply_waiter(self, msg_id, timeout): if wait_conditions: cond = wait_conditions.pop() with cond: cond.notify() with cond: cond.wait() return orig_reply_waiter(self, msg_id, timeout) self.stubs.Set(amqpdriver.ReplyWaiter, 'wait', reply_waiter) def send_and_wait_for_reply(i): replies.append(driver.send(target, {}, {'tx_id': i}, wait_for_reply=True, timeout=None)) while len(senders) < 2: t = threading.Thread(target=send_and_wait_for_reply, args=(len(senders), )) t.daemon = True senders.append(t) # Start the first guy, receive his message, but delay his polling notify_condition = threading.Condition() wait_conditions.append(notify_condition) with notify_condition: senders[0].start() notify_condition.wait() msgs.append(listener.poll()) self.assertEqual({'tx_id': 0}, msgs[-1].message) # Start the second guy, receive his message senders[1].start() msgs.append(listener.poll()) self.assertEqual({'tx_id': 1}, msgs[-1].message) # Reply to both in order, making the second thread queue # the reply meant for the first thread msgs[0].reply({'rx_id': 0}) msgs[1].reply({'rx_id': 1}) # Wait for the second thread to finish senders[1].join() # Let the first thread continue with notify_condition: notify_condition.notify() # Wait for the first thread to finish senders[0].join() # Verify replies were received out of order self.assertEqual(len(senders), len(replies)) self.assertEqual({'rx_id': 1}, replies[0]) self.assertEqual({'rx_id': 0}, replies[1])

commit_message:
Moved all tests to unit folder

This is a preparational patch to add functional and performance test
suites. Such suites will be launched by a separate tox env and a
separate jenkins job

Change-Id: I35bffb038bd8cbd053ff57541a088a1e3775464a

commit_message:
Moved main loop to server class

This will allow us to simplify dispatchers, executors and provide means
to implement custom Server class if needed.

Corresponding spec - https://review.openstack.org/#/c/105796/

Change-Id: Ifbc135ac94579ec9412843b87e069956dc353552
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging refs/changes/38/107038/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-10-10 15:19:13.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging/commit/3d296e1396ee6ad17b3dba5a5eef003b65b7a414', 'message': "Implement message flow control using link credit

This change implements a scheme for managing link credit for consumer
links.  There are two different link use cases in this driver, each
of which employs its own credit management scheme:

The per-connection RPC reply link: the RPC sender is rate limited
given the synchronous nature of the RPC implementation.  Also, we need
to avoid having a 'slow' RPC client block an RPC server. Therefore the
shared RPC reply link does not backpressure senders.  It maintains a
credit level in the range of [$reply_credit ... 2*$reply_credit]: a
batch of $reply_credit credits are granted whenever the current credit
level drops below $reply_credit.

The per-target RPC server links: the RPC servers need to be able to
backpressure the RPC clients should the server's backlog of incoming
RPC request messages becomes 'excessive'.  This is done by
implementing a high/low watermark on the queue of incoming RPC request
messages.  When the number of queued RPC request messages becomes
greater than $listener_max_backlog, the driver will stop granting
credit on all receive links associated with the RPC server's
subscription to its target.  When the number of queued RPC requests
drops to less than $listener_low_backlog, credit will resume being
granted to the receive links.  The scheme for maintaining credit on
the topic's receive links (when not blocking) is similar to the method
used for the per-connection RPC reply link: the credit level on all
links is maintained in the range [$subscription_credit
... 2*$subscription_credit].

Closes-Bug: #1367911

commit_message:
Implement message flow control using link credit

This change implements a scheme for managing link credit for consumer
links.  There are two different link use cases in this driver, each
of which employs its own credit management scheme:

The per-connection RPC reply link: the RPC sender is rate limited
given the synchronous nature of the RPC implementation.  Also, we need
to avoid having a 'slow' RPC client block an RPC server. Therefore the
shared RPC reply link does not backpressure senders.  It maintains a
credit level in the range of [$reply_credit/2 ... $reply_credit].

The per-target RPC server links: the RPC servers need to be able to
backpressure the broker should the server's backlog of incoming RPC
request messages becomes 'excessive'.  This is done by implementing a
high/low watermark on the queue of incoming RPC request messages.
When the number of queued RPC request messages becomes greater than
$listener_max_backlog, the driver will stop granting credit on all
receive links associated with the RPC server's subscription to its
target.  When the number of queued RPC requests drops to less than
$listener_low_backlog, credit will resume being granted to the receive
links.  The scheme for maintaining credit on the topic's receive links
(when not blocking) is similar to the method used for the
per-connection RPC reply link: the credit level on all links is
maintained in the range [$subscription_credit/2
... $subscription_credit].

Change-Id: If2a00139123d069d6968d6451d974d8aa183dcc4
Closes-Bug: #1367911
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging refs/changes/50/127550/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import abcfrom oslo.config import cfgfrom oslo.messaging._drivers.protocols.amqp import optsclass SynchronousCommand(controller.Task): """Base class that provides a synchronous function call interface to controller commands. def __init__(self, driver): super(SynchronousCommand, self).__init__() self._driver = driver self._done = threading.Event() self._results = None def __call__(self, **kwargs): """Invoke 'command' on the controller task, and wait for the result """ self._kwargs = kwargs self._driver._ctrl.add_task(self) self._done.wait() self._done.clear() return self._results # the following methods run on the eventloop thread: @abc.abstractmethod def command(self, controller, **kwargs): """Define the command to run on the controller""" pass # runs on the controller class - do not call directly! self._results = self.command(controller, **self._kwargs) self._done.set() class ListenTask(SynchronousCommand): """A task that creates a subscription to the given target. Messages arriving from the target are put on a queue. """ def __init__(self, driver): """Defines a command that creates a subscription to the target, and returns a handle to the subscription to the caller. Arguments: cmd(target=$t, in_queue=$q, [notifications=True|False]) super(ListenTask, self).__init__(driver) def command(self, controller, **kwargs): """Run on the eventloop thread - subscribes to target. Inbound messages are queued to the in_queue. """ in_queue = kwargs['in_queue'] target = kwargs['target'] if kwargs.get('notifications', False): return controller.subscribe_notifications(target, in_queue) else: return controller.subscribe(target, in_queue) class SubscriptionCreditCommand(SynchronousCommand): def __init__(self, driver): """Defines a command that enables or disables automatic credit renewal by the controller task for a given subscription. Arguments: cmd(subscription=$s, credit='enabled'|'disabled') """ super(SubscriptionCreditCommand, self).__init__(driver) def command(self, controller, **kwargs): subscription = kwargs['subscription'] credit = kwargs['credit'] if credit == 'disabled': controller.subscription_disable_credit(subscription) else: controller.subscription_enable_credit(subscription) def __init__(self, driver, targets, notifications=False, max_backlog=0, low_backlog=0): # queue of received messages pending for poll() self._max_backlog = max_backlog self._low_backlog = low_backlog self._blocking = False self._subscriptions = [ListenTask(driver)(target=t, in_queue=self.incoming, notifications=notifications) for t in targets] if self._blocking and self.incoming.qsize() < self._low_backlog: self._blocking = False self._enable_credit() if (not self._blocking and self._max_backlog and self.incoming.qsize() > self._max_backlog): self._blocking = True self._disable_credit() def _enable_credit(self): cmd = SubscriptionCreditCommand(self.driver) for s in self._subscriptions: cmd(subscription=s, credit='enabled') def _disable_credit(self): cmd = SubscriptionCreditCommand(self.driver) for s in self._subscriptions: cmd(subscription=s, credit='disabled') opt_group = cfg.OptGroup(name='oslo_messaging_amqp', title='AMQP 1.0 driver options') conf.register_group(opt_group) conf.register_opts(opts.amqp1_opts, group=opt_group) self._listener_max_backlog = \ conf.oslo_messaging_amqp.listener_max_backlog self._listener_low_backlog = \ conf.oslo_messaging_amqp.listener_low_backlog return ProtonListener(self, [target], max_backlog=self._listener_max_backlog, low_backlog=self._listener_low_backlog) targets = [messaging_target.Target(topic="%s.%s" % (t.topic, p)) for t, p in targets_and_priorities] return ProtonListener(self, targets, notifications=True, max_backlog=self._listener_max_backlog, low_backlog=self._listener_low_backlog)
deleted_lines: class ListenTask(controller.Task): """A task that creates a subscription to the given target. Messages arriving from the target are given to the listener. def __init__(self, target, listener, notifications=False): """Create a subscription to the target.""" super(ListenTask, self).__init__() self._target = target self._listener = listener self._notifications = notifications """Run on the eventloop thread - subscribes to target. Inbound messages are queued to the listener's incoming queue. if self._notifications: controller.subscribe_notifications(self._target, self._listener.incoming) else: controller.subscribe(self._target, self._listener.incoming) def __init__(self, driver): listener = ProtonListener(self) self._ctrl.add_task(ListenTask(target, listener)) return listener listener = ProtonListener(self) for target, priority in targets_and_priorities: topic = '%s.%s' % (target.topic, priority) t = messaging_target.Target(topic=topic) self._ctrl.add_task(ListenTask(t, listener, True)) return listener

commit_message:
Remove set_time_override in timeutils

The set_time_override function in timeutils was written as a
helper function to mock utcnow for unittests before 'mock' was
generally used. Now that we have mock and fixture, we no longer
need to use it.

Change-Id: I4d4af4933237b2ab424329c66ce792e7cb4f2a00
Closes-Bug: #1266962
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.utils refs/changes/13/137813/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: import timefrom testtools import matchers self.addCleanup(timeutils.clear_time_override) def test_set_time_override_using_default(self): now = timeutils.utcnow_ts() # NOTE(kgriffs): Normally it's bad form to sleep in a unit test, # but this is the only way to test that set_time_override defaults # to setting the override to the current time. time.sleep(1) timeutils.set_time_override() overriden_now = timeutils.utcnow_ts() self.assertThat(now, matchers.LessThan(overriden_now)) # NOTE(kgriffs): timeutils.utcnow_ts() uses time.time() # IFF time override is not set. timeutils.set_time_override(skynet_dt) ts = timeutils.utcnow_ts() self.assertEqual(ts, skynet_self_aware_ts) def test_utcnow(self): timeutils.set_time_override(mock.sentinel.utcnow) self.assertEqual(timeutils.utcnow(), mock.sentinel.utcnow) timeutils.clear_time_override() self.assertFalse(timeutils.utcnow() == mock.sentinel.utcnow) self.assertTrue(timeutils.utcnow()) def test_advance_time_delta(self): timeutils.set_time_override(self.one_minute_before) timeutils.advance_time_delta(datetime.timedelta(seconds=60)) self.assertEqual(timeutils.utcnow(), self.skynet_self_aware_time) def test_advance_time_seconds(self): timeutils.set_time_override(self.one_minute_before) timeutils.advance_time_seconds(60) self.assertEqual(timeutils.utcnow(), self.skynet_self_aware_time)

commit_message:
Check cli parameter when checking if the option is already registered

Currently, if we register some options using both register_opts()
and register_cli_opts(). The register_cli_opts() will ignore as
the option is though already registerd. Hence no option will
appear with '-h' parameter, and the option is not registered as
cli options.

I fix this bug by checking the cli parameter passed to the
_is_opt_registered() method.

Change-Id: Ib096157ea05a6bfb7a8da812a8f9190d925da88b
Closes-Bug: 1363808

commit_message:
Allow to reference values outside DEFAULT in substitution

This change allows use to reference values in form ${group.name}. User
also can reference values from the same group by omitting group name:
${.name}. Usage example:

  [DEFAULT]
  someservice_url=${someservice.url}
  [someservice]
  url=http://${.host}:${.port}
  host=someservice.example.com
  port=80

Change-Id: Iac68943e83975ac40afbc20a79a4c12bb1dcef34
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.config refs/changes/84/103884/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Support groups in option value interpolation

This change enhances the option value interpolation feature to support
interpolation across groups. The template syntax to reference an option
in another group is ${group.option} (the brackets are required).

Change-Id: I98dae021852f1ac646bd17f44d96717c7687fec8
Implements: blueprint group-option-interpolation

commit_message:
Handle WSME errors in clients

WSME errors contains ``faultcode`` and ``faultstring``, plus an
optional ``debuginfo`` attribute.

Change-Id: Ic16661d3d266770383f786bd3ade68c629bf758f
Closes-bug: #1354470

commit_message:
Moved main loop to server class

This will allow us to simplify dispatchers, executors and provide means
to implement custom Server class if needed.

Restored from: Ifbc135ac94579ec9412843b87e069956dc353552

Corresponding spec - https://review.openstack.org/#/c/133668/

Change-Id: If045d5199f2f743c0e4f0249928ca697b7e3fdeb

commit_message:
Adds message security plugins

This adds an optional plugin framework for message security. It
also provides two plugin implementations, a dummy pass through
and one for using kite.

Change-Id: Icbed9d0aee4c84bb396f58bcb7516797a97a515b
Implements: blueprint trusted-messaging
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging refs/changes/06/109806/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2014 HP, Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from oslo.messaging import security from keystoneclient.auth import token_endpoint from keystoneclient import session from kiteclient import v1 import ast import logging def getSession(): # NOTE(tkelsey): using developer interface to remove the need to run # a keystone server. host = "localhost" port = 9109 kite = "http://%s:%s/v1" % (host, port) auth = token_endpoint.Token(kite, 'aToken') return session.Session(auth=auth) class KiteSecPolicy(security.SecurityPolicyBase): """This security policy provides message level security through the use of Kite. A Kite server and a Keystone server must be available. """ log = logging.getLogger(__name__) class _ListenerWrapper(security.SecurityListenerBase): def __init__(self, listener, key): super(KiteSecPolicy._ListenerWrapper, self).__init__( listener) KiteSecPolicy.log.debug("Listening") self._key = key def __call__(self, message): self.listener.__call__(message) def poll(self, timeout=None): message = self.listener.poll(timeout=timeout) if message: KiteSecPolicy.log.debug("Got secure message: %s", message.message) esek = v1.Esek(message.message["sender"], self._key, message.message["esek"]) body = esek.decrypt(message.message["body"], message.message["signature"], b64decode=True) KiteSecPolicy.log.debug("Decrypted message: %s", body) message.message = ast.literal_eval(body) return message def __init__(self, identity, key=None): super(KiteSecPolicy, self).__init__(identity) self.log.debug("Peer identified as %s" % identity) self._session = getSession() if key is None: self._key = v1.Key.generate(self.identity, self._session) else: self._key = v1.Key(self.identity, key, self._session) def _get_ticket(self, target): ticket = v1.Ticket(self._key, target.topic, session=self._session) return ticket def secure(self, target, message): """Secure a message to a given target.""" self.log.debug("Securing Message: %s", message) ticket = self._get_ticket(target) enc, sig = ticket.encrypt(str(message)) data = { "sender": self._key.key_name, "body": enc, "signature": sig, "esek": ticket.b64_esek } self.log.debug("Securred Message: %s", data) return data def listen(self, listener): """Wrap a Listener and decode incoming messages.""" wrapper = KiteSecPolicy._ListenerWrapper(listener, self._key) return wrapper

subject: Allow parsing of key/value lines with leading whitespace
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-07-19 15:04:04.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.config/commit/919ddf468a691fd1d88fda7dbb8e29b1f907c01e', 'message': "Allow parsing of key/value lines with leading whitespace.

Removing a hash from a line in a config file without also removing
the leading space on the line leads to a parsing error.  The
problem occurs because any line starting with a space is assumed
to be the second parameter in a 'multiline' key/value assignment.

The proposed fix allows for the multiline assignment and allows
any line to have leading whitespace by requiring than any
additional lines in a multiline assignment do not have colons or
equals signs.  If a line does have a colon or equals sign, it's
considered a new key/value assignment.

If and when configuration files are more standardized, this
parsing behavior should be revisited.  At this point, though, it
fixes the reported bug and passes all the other parsing tests as
well.

Closes-Bug: 1266832

Change-Id: Ie20fd3b99bb757c74ee00012539fc71e0d68fc16
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-07-19 16:34:25.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.config/commit/7cf891a9595be5ae8fbbb05d8dc338d53c18b58e', 'message': "Allow parsing of key/value lines with leading whitespace

The proposed fix allows for the multiline assignment and allows

If and when configuration files are more standardized, this

Closes-Bug: 1266832

Change-Id: Ie20fd3b99bb757c74ee00012539fc71e0d68fc16

any line to have leading whitespace by requiring than any
additional lines in a multiline assignment do not have colons or
equals signs.  If a line does have a colon or equals sign, it's
considered a new key/value assignment.

If and when configuration files are more standardized, this
parsing behavior should be revisited.  At this point, though, it
fixes the reported bug and passes all the other parsing tests as
well.

Closes-Bug: 1266832

Change-Id: Ie20fd3b99bb757c74ee00012539fc71e0d68fc16
"}]
commit_message:
Allow parsing of key/value lines with leading whitespace

Removing a hash from a line in a config file without also removing
the leading space on the line leads to a parsing error.  The
problem occurs because any line starting with a space is assumed
to be the second parameter in a 'multiline' key/value assignment.

The proposed fix allows for the multiline assignment and allows
any line to have leading whitespace by requiring than any
additional lines in a multiline assignment do not have colons or
equals signs.  If a line does have a colon or equals sign, it's
considered a new key/value assignment.

If and when configuration files are more standardized, this
parsing behavior should be revisited.  At this point, though, it
fixes the reported bug and passes all the other parsing tests as
well.

Closes-Bug: 1266832

Change-Id: Ie20fd3b99bb757c74ee00012539fc71e0d68fc16

commit_message:
Warn if new and deprecated options are both present

Its possibly a misconfiguration if both new and deprecated
versions of an option are configured at the same time.  The
recommendation has been to log a warning when this is detected.

I've included group, name, and value for any such options as
debugging aid.

Change-Id: I10951d0ec4df2688540e95eef3dd7a913a5da4b9
Closes-Bug: 1319868
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.config refs/changes/91/121691/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _all_opts_with_dopts(self): """A generator function for iterating opts having deprecated opts.""" for info, group in self._all_opt_infos(): if len(info['opt'].deprecated_opts): yield info['opt'], group self._check_new_and_deprecated(namespace) def _check_new_and_deprecated(self, namespace): '''Warn if both deprecated and newer versions of an option are present. Log a warning if both deprecated and newer versions of an option are present at the same time, as this is possibly a misconfiguration. ''' # Only bother looking at options that have duplicated_opts. for opt, group in self._all_opts_with_dopts(): group_name = group.name if group is not None else 'DEFAULT' dnames = [] # Build list of deprecated options. for dopt in opt.deprecated_opts: dname, dgroup = dopt.name, dopt.group if dname is not None: dgroup = dgroup if dgroup is not None else group_name dnames.append((dgroup, dname)) names = [(group_name, opt.name)] try: # If a value is configured for this option and at least one # deprecated option v = namespace._parser._get(names, multi=False, normalized=True) namespace._parser._get(dnames, multi=True, normalized=True) except KeyError: pass else: # Provide option name and value as an aid to diagnose issue. msg = [("Possible misconfiguration. Found both new and " "deprecated versions of option '[%s] %s=%s'." % (names[0][0], names[0][1], v[0]))] # It is possible to have multiple deprecated options. for g, n in dnames: try: v = namespace._parser._get([(g, n)], multi=False, normalized=True) except KeyError: pass else: msg.append("Deprecated option is '[%s] %s=%s'." % (g, n, v[0])) LOG.warn(' '.join(msg))

commit_message:
Add load_config_file function

When developing I4b860e3f7901b00b1c78f7df1f2219132f347239 I found it
difficult provide a small, additional config-file snippet that
unit-tests could use to test the new config-option provided.

My suggestion is to provide a load_config_file() function that simply
parses adds a given config-file into the existing name-space.

I think this would enhance the ability of certain unit-tests, such as
for the change above, to be "end-to-end" ... that is to test the
values are read correctly from the config file into oslo.config and
used correctly in the program.

Change-Id: I26f5132e6323340617dd9448661e325ff3f509e3

commit_message:
Add a ProxyConfigOpts derivative (WIP)

Add a new subclass of _CachedConfigOpts that can ask a provided
object for values (that provided object could be a dictionary,
a webservice, something else...), it will also be able to notify
some provided object when options are registered, unregistered and
so-on (so that the provided object may adjust its own information
if it needs to).

An example that shows the usage of this is at:

http://paste.ubuntu.com/9113641/

With output at:

http://paste.ubuntu.com/9113668/

Change-Id: I21b1914b490f3ac5722a5263a764c5eb60a4073e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.config refs/changes/47/135847/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class ProxyConfigOpts(_CachedConfigOpts): """This configuration option derivative supports proxy fetching...""" def __init__(self, retriever, notifier=None): super(ProxyConfigOpts, self).__init__() if not six.callable(retriever): raise ValueError("Option retriever must be callable") self._retriever = retriever self._notifier = notifier def _do_get(self, name, group=None, namespace=None): return self._retriever(name, group=group, namespace=namespace) def clear(self): super(ProxyConfigOpts, self).clear() if self._notifier is not None: self._notifier.notify_cleared(self) def register_group(self, group): super(ProxyConfigOpts, self).register_group(group) if self._notifier is not None: self._notifier.notify_group_registered(self, group) def unregister_opt(self, opt, group=None): super(ProxyConfigOpts, self).unregister_opt(opt, group=group) if self._notifier is not None: self._notifier.notify_opt_unregistered(self, opt, group=group) def register_opt(self, opt, group=None, **kwargs): super(ProxyConfigOpts, self).register_opt(opt, group=group, **kwargs) if self._notifier is not None: self._notifier.notify_opt_registered(self, opt, group=group)

commit_message:
Refactor config opts, deriving from common base (WIP)

Start to shift the functionality of the config opts class
into a base class that allows for other implementations of
config opts that can provide there own implementations of
the base abstract methods (perhaps providing a '_do_get' that
fetchs from a remote source, or from a dictionary, or from
elsewhere).

This is a first step at decoupling oslo.config from being so
tied to CLI and config file parsing, extraction... so that in
the future more flexible and alternative sources can easily
co-exist.

Change-Id: Id2e194fbdf7310c3cf704f1a1b96f07292420d3b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.config refs/changes/71/134671/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import abc@six.add_metaclass(abc.ABCMeta) class _BaseConfigOpts(collections.Mapping): """Config options which may be set/retrieved from some source. _BaseConfigOpts is a configuration option manager with APIs for registering option schemas, grouping options, parsing option values and retrieving the values of options. """ class StrSubWrapper(object): """Helper class. Exposes opt values as a dict for string substitution. """ def __init__(self, conf, group=None, namespace=None): """Construct a StrSubWrapper object. :param conf: a ConfigOpts object """ self.conf = conf self.namespace = namespace self.group = group def __getitem__(self, key): """Look up an opt value from the ConfigOpts object. :param key: an opt name :returns: an opt value :raises: TemplateSubstitutionError if attribute is a group """ try: value = self.conf._get(key, group=self.group, namespace=self.namespace) except NoSuchOptError: value = self.conf._get(key, namespace=self.namespace) if isinstance(value, self.conf.GroupAttr): raise TemplateSubstitutionError( 'substituting group %s not supported' % key) return value def __init__(self): self._opts = {} # dict of dicts of (opt:, override:, default:) self._groups = {} def __getattr__(self, name): """Look up an option value and perform string substitution. :param name: the opt name (or 'dest', more precisely) :returns: the option value (after string substitution) or a GroupAttr :raises: NoSuchOptError """ try: return self._get(name) except Exception: raise NoSuchOptError(name) def __getitem__(self, key): """Look up an option value and perform string substitution.""" return self.__getattr__(key) def __contains__(self, key): """Return True if key is the name of a registered opt or group.""" return key in self._opts or key in self._groups def __iter__(self): """Iterate over all registered opt and group names.""" for key in itertools.chain(self._opts.keys(), self._groups.keys()): yield key def __len__(self): """Return the number of options and option groups.""" return len(self._opts) + len(self._groups) @abc.abstractmethod def _do_get(self, name, group=None, namespace=None): """Look up an option value. :param name: the opt name (or 'dest', more precisely) :param group: an OptGroup :param namespace: the namespace object that retrieves the option value from :returns: the option value, or a GroupAttr object :raises: NoSuchOptError, NoSuchGroupError, ConfigFileValueError, TemplateSubstitutionError """ def _all_opt_infos(self): """A generator function for iteration opt infos.""" for info in self._opts.values(): yield info, None for group in self._groups.values(): for info in group._opts.values(): yield info, group def _unset_defaults_and_overrides(self): """Unset any default or override on all options.""" for info, group in self._all_opt_infos(): info.pop('default', None) info.pop('override', None) def _check_required_opts(self, namespace=None): """Check that all opts marked as required have values specified. :param namespace: the namespace object be checked the required options :raises: RequiredOptError """ for info, group in self._all_opt_infos(): opt = info['opt'] if opt.required: if 'default' in info or 'override' in info: continue if self._get(opt.dest, group, namespace) is None: raise RequiredOptError(opt.name, group) def _get_opt_info(self, opt_name, group=None): """Return the (opt, override, default) dict for an opt. :param opt_name: an opt name/dest :param group: an optional group name or OptGroup object :raises: NoSuchOptError, NoSuchGroupError """ if group is None: opts = self._opts else: group = self._get_group(group) opts = group._opts if opt_name not in opts: raise NoSuchOptError(opt_name, group) return opts[opt_name] def _get_group(self, group_or_name, autocreate=False): """Looks up a OptGroup object. Helper function to return an OptGroup given a parameter which can either be the group's name or an OptGroup object. The OptGroup object returned is from the internal dict of OptGroup objects, which will be a copy of any OptGroup object that users of the API have access to. If autocreate is True, the group will be created if it's not found. If group is an instance of OptGroup, that same instance will be registered, otherwise a new instance of OptGroup will be created. :param group_or_name: the group's name or the OptGroup object itself :param autocreate: whether to auto-create the group if it's not found :raises: NoSuchGroupError """ group = group_or_name if isinstance(group_or_name, OptGroup) else None group_name = group.name if group else group_or_name if group_name not in self._groups: if not autocreate: raise NoSuchGroupError(group_name) self.register_group(group or OptGroup(name=group_name)) return self._groups[group_name] def _substitute(self, value, group=None, namespace=None): """Perform string template substitution. Substitute any template variables (for example $foo, ${bar}) in the supplied string value(s) with opt values. :param value: the string value, or list of string values :param group: the group that retrieves the option value from :param namespace: the namespace object that retrieves the option value from :returns: the substituted string(s) """ if isinstance(value, list): return [self._substitute(i, group=group, namespace=namespace) for i in value] elif isinstance(value, str): # Treat a backslash followed by the dollar sign "\$" # the same as the string template escape "$$" as it is # a bit more natural for users if '\$' in value: value = value.replace('\$', '$$') tmpl = string.Template(value) ret = tmpl.safe_substitute( self.StrSubWrapper(self, group=group, namespace=namespace)) return ret else: return value def _convert_value(self, value, opt): """Perform value type conversion. Converts values using option's type. Handles cases when value is actually a list of values (for example for multi opts). :param value: the string value, or list of string values :param opt: option definition (instance of Opt class or its subclasses) :returns: converted value """ if opt.multi: return [opt.type(v) for v in value] else: return opt.type(value) @abc.abstractmethod def clear(self): """Clear the state of the object to before it was called.""" @abc.abstractmethod def reset(self): """Clear the object state and unset overrides and defaults.""" @abc.abstractmethod def register_opt(self, opt, group=None, **kwargs): """Register an option schema. Registering an option schema makes any option value which is previously or subsequently parsed from the command line or config files available as an attribute of this object. :param opt: an instance of an Opt sub-class :param group: an optional OptGroup object or group name :return: False if the opt was already registered, True otherwise :raises: DuplicateOptError """ def register_group(self, group): """Register an option group. An option group must be registered before options can be registered with the group. :param group: an OptGroup object """ if group.name in self._groups: return self._groups[group.name] = copy.copy(group) def register_opts(self, opts, group=None, **kwargs): """Register multiple option schemas at once.""" for opt in opts: self.register_opt(opt, group=group, **kwargs) def unregister_opt(self, opt, group=None): """Unregister an option. :param opt: an Opt object :param group: an optional OptGroup object or group name :raises: ArgsAlreadyParsedError, NoSuchGroupError """ if self._args is not None: raise ArgsAlreadyParsedError("reset before unregistering options") if group is not None: self._get_group(group)._unregister_opt(opt) elif opt.dest in self._opts: del self._opts[opt.dest] def unregister_opts(self, opts, group=None): """Unregister multiple CLI option schemas at once.""" for opt in opts: self.unregister_opt(opt, group, clear_cache=False) def set_override(self, name, override, group=None): """Override an opt value. Override the command line, config file and default values of a given option. :param name: the name/dest of the opt :param override: the override value :param group: an option OptGroup object or group name :raises: NoSuchOptError, NoSuchGroupError """ opt_info = self._get_opt_info(name, group) opt_info['override'] = override def set_default(self, name, default, group=None): """Override an opt's default value. Override the default value of given option. A command line or config file value will still take precedence over this default. :param name: the name/dest of the opt :param default: the default value :param group: an option OptGroup object or group name :raises: NoSuchOptError, NoSuchGroupError """ opt_info = self._get_opt_info(name, group) opt_info['default'] = default def clear_override(self, name, group=None): """Clear an override an opt value. Clear a previously set override of the command line, config file and default values of a given option. :param name: the name/dest of the opt :param group: an option OptGroup object or group name :raises: NoSuchOptError, NoSuchGroupError """ opt_info = self._get_opt_info(name, group) opt_info.pop('override', None) def clear_default(self, name, group=None): """Clear an override an opt's default value. Clear a previously set override of the default value of given option. :param name: the name/dest of the opt :param group: an option OptGroup object or group name :raises: NoSuchOptError, NoSuchGroupError """ opt_info = self._get_opt_info(name, group) opt_info.pop('default', None) class ConfigOpts(_BaseConfigOpts): super(ConfigOpts, self).__init__() """Initialize a ConfigOpts object for option parsing.""" Calling a ConfigOpts object causes the supplied command line arguments and config files to be parsed, causing opt values to be made available as attributes of the object. super(ConfigOpts, self).register_opts(opts, group=group) super(ConfigOpts, self).unregister_opt(opt, group=group) super(ConfigOpts, self).unregister_opts(opts, group=group) def _get(self, name, group=None, namespace=None): if isinstance(group, OptGroup): key = (group.name, name) else: key = (group, name) try: if namespace is not None: raise KeyError return self.__cache[key] except KeyError: value = self._do_get(name, group, namespace) self.__cache[key] = value return value super(ConfigOpts, self).set_override(name, override, group=group) super(ConfigOpts, self).set_default(name, default, group=group) super(ConfigOpts, self).clear_override(name, group=group) super(ConfigOpts, self).clear_default(name, group=group)

Calling a ConfigOpts object causes the supplied command line arguments and config files to be parsed, causing opt values to be made available as attributes of the object. def __getattr__(self, name): """Look up an option value and perform string substitution. :param name: the opt name (or 'dest', more precisely) :returns: the option value (after string substitution) or a GroupAttr :raises: NoSuchOptError """ try: return self._get(name) except Exception: raise NoSuchOptError(name) def __getitem__(self, key): """Look up an option value and perform string substitution.""" return self.__getattr__(key) def __contains__(self, key): """Return True if key is the name of a registered opt or group.""" return key in self._opts or key in self._groups def __iter__(self): """Iterate over all registered opt and group names.""" for key in itertools.chain(self._opts.keys(), self._groups.keys()): yield key def __len__(self): """Return the number of options and option groups.""" return len(self._opts) + len(self._groups) """Register multiple option schemas at once.""" for opt in opts: self.register_opt(opt, group, clear_cache=False) def register_group(self, group): """Register an option group. An option group must be registered before options can be registered with the group. :param group: an OptGroup object """ if group.name in self._groups: return self._groups[group.name] = copy.copy(group) """Unregister an option. :param opt: an Opt object :param group: an optional OptGroup object or group name :raises: ArgsAlreadyParsedError, NoSuchGroupError """ if self._args is not None: raise ArgsAlreadyParsedError("reset before unregistering options") if group is not None: self._get_group(group)._unregister_opt(opt) elif opt.dest in self._opts: del self._opts[opt.dest] """Unregister multiple CLI option schemas at once.""" for opt in opts: self.unregister_opt(opt, group, clear_cache=False) """Override an opt value. Override the command line, config file and default values of a given option. :param name: the name/dest of the opt :param override: the override value :param group: an option OptGroup object or group name :raises: NoSuchOptError, NoSuchGroupError """ opt_info = self._get_opt_info(name, group) opt_info['override'] = override """Override an opt's default value. Override the default value of given option. A command line or config file value will still take precedence over this default. :param name: the name/dest of the opt :param default: the default value :param group: an option OptGroup object or group name :raises: NoSuchOptError, NoSuchGroupError """ opt_info = self._get_opt_info(name, group) opt_info['default'] = default """Clear an override an opt value. Clear a previously set override of the command line, config file and default values of a given option. :param name: the name/dest of the opt :param group: an option OptGroup object or group name :raises: NoSuchOptError, NoSuchGroupError """ opt_info = self._get_opt_info(name, group) opt_info.pop('override', None) """Clear an override an opt's default value. Clear a previously set override of the default value of given option. :param name: the name/dest of the opt :param group: an option OptGroup object or group name :raises: NoSuchOptError, NoSuchGroupError """ opt_info = self._get_opt_info(name, group) opt_info.pop('default', None) def _all_opt_infos(self): """A generator function for iteration opt infos.""" for info in self._opts.values(): yield info, None for group in self._groups.values(): for info in group._opts.values(): yield info, group def _unset_defaults_and_overrides(self): """Unset any default or override on all options.""" for info, group in self._all_opt_infos(): info.pop('default', None) info.pop('override', None) def _get(self, name, group=None, namespace=None): if isinstance(group, OptGroup): key = (group.name, name) else: key = (group, name) try: if namespace is not None: raise KeyError return self.__cache[key] except KeyError: value = self._do_get(name, group, namespace) self.__cache[key] = value return value def _substitute(self, value, group=None, namespace=None): """Perform string template substitution. Substitute any template variables (for example $foo, ${bar}) in the supplied string value(s) with opt values. :param value: the string value, or list of string values :param group: the group that retrieves the option value from :param namespace: the namespace object that retrieves the option value from :returns: the substituted string(s) """ if isinstance(value, list): return [self._substitute(i, group=group, namespace=namespace) for i in value] elif isinstance(value, str): # Treat a backslash followed by the dollar sign "\$" # the same as the string template escape "$$" as it is # a bit more natural for users if '\$' in value: value = value.replace('\$', '$$') tmpl = string.Template(value) ret = tmpl.safe_substitute( self.StrSubWrapper(self, group=group, namespace=namespace)) return ret else: return value def _convert_value(self, value, opt): """Perform value type conversion. Converts values using option's type. Handles cases when value is actually a list of values (for example for multi opts). :param value: the string value, or list of string values :param opt: option definition (instance of Opt class or its subclasses) :returns: converted value """ if opt.multi: return [opt.type(v) for v in value] else: return opt.type(value) def _get_group(self, group_or_name, autocreate=False): """Looks up a OptGroup object. Helper function to return an OptGroup given a parameter which can either be the group's name or an OptGroup object. The OptGroup object returned is from the internal dict of OptGroup objects, which will be a copy of any OptGroup object that users of the API have access to. If autocreate is True, the group will be created if it's not found. If group is an instance of OptGroup, that same instance will be registered, otherwise a new instance of OptGroup will be created. :param group_or_name: the group's name or the OptGroup object itself :param autocreate: whether to auto-create the group if it's not found :raises: NoSuchGroupError """ group = group_or_name if isinstance(group_or_name, OptGroup) else None group_name = group.name if group else group_or_name if group_name not in self._groups: if not autocreate: raise NoSuchGroupError(group_name) self.register_group(group or OptGroup(name=group_name)) return self._groups[group_name] def _get_opt_info(self, opt_name, group=None): """Return the (opt, override, default) dict for an opt. :param opt_name: an opt name/dest :param group: an optional group name or OptGroup object :raises: NoSuchOptError, NoSuchGroupError """ if group is None: opts = self._opts else: group = self._get_group(group) opts = group._opts if opt_name not in opts: raise NoSuchOptError(opt_name, group) return opts[opt_name] def _check_required_opts(self, namespace=None): """Check that all opts marked as required have values specified. :param namespace: the namespace object be checked the required options :raises: RequiredOptError """ for info, group in self._all_opt_infos(): opt = info['opt'] if opt.required: if 'default' in info or 'override' in info: continue if self._get(opt.dest, group, namespace) is None: raise RequiredOptError(opt.name, group) class StrSubWrapper(object): """Helper class. Exposes opt values as a dict for string substitution. """ def __init__(self, conf, group=None, namespace=None): """Construct a StrSubWrapper object. :param conf: a ConfigOpts object """ self.conf = conf self.namespace = namespace self.group = group def __getitem__(self, key): """Look up an opt value from the ConfigOpts object. :param key: an opt name :returns: an opt value :raises: TemplateSubstitutionError if attribute is a group """ try: value = self.conf._get(key, group=self.group, namespace=self.namespace) except NoSuchOptError: value = self.conf._get(key, namespace=self.namespace) if isinstance(value, self.conf.GroupAttr): raise TemplateSubstitutionError( 'substituting group %s not supported' % key) return value

commit_message:
Add an option for late acknowledgement in RPC

In order to use RPC cast as a simple work queue, the RPC dispatcher
must be able to send the ACK only after it's finished executing
the callback, so the message can be delivered to another server
in case this one crashes mid-callback.

The parameter is optional and the default behaviour doesn't change
so it won't impact the current use of RPC in OpenStack projects.

Change-Id: Idaa03271dc4b054979df276ca47b583900b5062b
Closes-bug: #1350212

commit_message:
`publisher`function separated into ZmqProxy method

In the `consume` method of ZmqProxy class declared a function named
`publisher`. This function contains reach socket data sending logic. This
function became the instance method named `_publisher`.

Such an approach is much easier to test and improve logic of the
function.

Change-Id: I769f0616726785a6b0e60d84072f7446b5a29e34
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging refs/changes/98/124098/16 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _publisher(self, waiter, topic): LOG.info(_("Creating proxy for topic: %s"), topic) try: # The topic is received over the network, # don't trust this input. if self.badchars.search(topic) is not None: emsg = _("Topic contained dangerous characters.") LOG.warn(emsg) raise RPCException(emsg) ipc_dir = self.conf.oslo_messaging_zmq.ipc_dir out_sock = ZmqSocket("ipc://%s/zmq_topic_%s" % (ipc_dir, topic), sock_type, bind=True) except RPCException: waiter.send_exception(*sys.exc_info()) return self.topic_proxy[topic] = eventlet.queue.LightQueue( CONF.rpc_zmq.topic_backlog) self.sockets.append(out_sock) # It takes some time for a pub socket to open, # before we can have any faith in doing a send() to it. if sock_type == zmq.PUB: eventlet.sleep(.5) waiter.send(True) while(True): data = self.topic_proxy[topic].get() out_sock.send(data, copy=False) def consume(self, sock): data = sock.recv(copy=False) topic = data[1].bytes if topic not in self.topic_proxy: eventlet.spawn(self._publisher, wait_sock_creation, topic)
deleted_lines: def consume(self, sock): ipc_dir = self.conf.oslo_messaging_zmq.ipc_dir data = sock.recv(copy=False) topic = data[1].bytes if topic not in self.topic_proxy: def publisher(waiter): LOG.info(_("Creating proxy for topic: %s"), topic) try: # The topic is received over the network, # don't trust this input. if self.badchars.search(topic) is not None: emsg = _("Topic contained dangerous characters.") LOG.warn(emsg) raise RPCException(emsg) out_sock = ZmqSocket("ipc://%s/zmq_topic_%s" % (ipc_dir, topic), sock_type, bind=True) except RPCException: waiter.send_exception(*sys.exc_info()) return self.topic_proxy[topic] = eventlet.queue.LightQueue( CONF.rpc_zmq_topic_backlog) self.sockets.append(out_sock) # It takes some time for a pub socket to open, # before we can have any faith in doing a send() to it. if sock_type == zmq.PUB: eventlet.sleep(.5) waiter.send(True) while(True): data = self.topic_proxy[topic].get() out_sock.send(data, copy=False) eventlet.spawn(publisher, wait_sock_creation)

commit_message:
Helper method to check and restrict socket name

ZMQ IPC socket paths limited to 107 characters in length. Thus we need
to check and restrict it.
Closes-Bug: #1367614
Change-Id: I5e7d379e543fd2fd14956482542fe074e9fbca17

added_lines: import hashlib def _compose_sock_name(self, topic): ipc_dir = self.conf.oslo_messaging_zmq.ipc_dir sock_name = "ipc://%s/zmq_topic_" % ipc_dir if len(sock_name) + len(topic) > 107: # NOTE(I159): The guess that length of a dir path # and zmq prefix can't be greater than 107 - 32. return sock_name + hashlib.md5(topic).hexdigest() return sock_name + topic out_sock = ZmqSocket(self.conf, self._compose_sock_name(topic),
deleted_lines: ipc_dir = self.conf.oslo_messaging_zmq.ipc_dir out_sock = ZmqSocket("ipc://%s/zmq_topic_%s" % (ipc_dir, topic),

commit_message:
Topic object

Topic manipulations are significant part of Zero MQ driver. All of these
actions were performed in-line as string operations. This kind of design
is very difficult to debug and modify. We to have a single entry point
for topic to reduce the described issues.

* Created Topic object with appropriate methods to manipulate and
control topic value.
* Extended Target object to use Topic object with normal Target
features.
* To restrict and standardize topic length used md5 hexdigest (with
length of 32 chars) value as base topic name. md5 used to have guaranteed the
same value for the same seed in different threads or even nodes.

Change-Id: Icd674d92c94be21ed9ac037fa6c5bd132b00340e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging refs/changes/20/144120/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import copy import functools import hashlibimport randomfrom oslo import messagingdef _copy_topic_instance(f): @functools.wraps(f) def wrap(inst, *args, **kwargs): new_inst = copy.deepcopy(inst) return f(new_inst, *args, **kwargs) return wrap class Topic(object): _value = None def __init__(self, conf, seed=None): self.conf = conf # NOTE(I159): the value of topic could be ''. It can cause a problem self._value = hashlib.md5(seed).hexdigest() if seed else self._value if seed and '.' in seed: self._value = self._set_dot() def __str__(self): return self._value def __eq__(self, other): return str(self) == str(other) def _set_dot(self): chr_list = [i for i in self._value] chr_list[random.randint(1, 30)] = '.' return ''.join([i for i in self._value]) def set_with_dash(self): self._value = self._value.replace('.', '-', 1) @_copy_topic_instance def get_fanout(self): self._value = 'fanout~' + self._value return self @_copy_topic_instance def get_hosted(self, host=None): self._value = "%s.%s" % (self._value.split('.')[0], host or self.conf.oslo_messaging_zmq.host) return self @_copy_topic_instance def get_with_dash(self): self._value = self._value.replace('.', '-', 1) return self @_copy_topic_instance def priorytize(self, priority): self._value = "%s-%s" % ( self._value, priority) if self._value else None return self @_copy_topic_instance def get_replies(self): self._value = "%s_%s" % ('zmq_replies', self._value) return self @classmethod def wrap(cls, conf, topic): topic_obj = cls(conf) topic_obj._value = topic return topic_obj def is_fanout(self): return self._value.startswith('fanout~') def is_replies(self): return self._value.startswith('zmq_replies') class TopicDescriptor(object): """Base topic as unique value with the length of 32 symbols. To standardize topics management a topic should be unique and has a constant length. """ _topic = collections.namedtuple('TopicType', ('seed', 'hex')) def __set__(self, obj, seed): self._topic = Topic(obj.conf, seed) def __get__(self, obj, objtype): return self._topic class ZmqTarget(messaging.Target): """Target object with controlled topic.""" def __init__(self, conf, **kwargs): self.conf = conf super(ZmqTarget, self).__init__(**kwargs) topic = TopicDescriptor() if topic.is_fanout(): elif topic.is_replies(): ipc_dir = self.conf.oslo_messaging_zmq.ipc_dir out_sock = ZmqSocket(self.conf, "ipc://%s/zmq_topic_%s" % (ipc_dir, topic), sock_type, bind=True) while True: topic = Topic.wrap(self.conf, data[1].bytes) topic = topic.get_fanout() topic = topic.get_hosted() reply_topic = Topic(conf, 'replies').get_replies().get_hosted() 'topic': str(reply_topic), "ipc://%s/zmq_topic_%s" % reply_topic), queues = _get_matchmaker(conf).queues(str(topic)) topic = target.topic.get_fanout() elif target.server: topic = target.topic.get_hosted(target.server) else: topic = target.topic target.topic.set_with_dash() topic = target.topic.priorytize(priority) conn.create_consumer(topic, listener)
deleted_lines: if topic.startswith('fanout~'): topic = topic.split('.', 1)[0] elif topic.startswith('zmq_replies'): try: # The topic is received over the network, # don't trust this input. if self.badchars.search(topic) is not None: emsg = _("Topic contained dangerous characters.") LOG.warn(emsg) raise RPCException(emsg) ipc_dir = self.conf.oslo_messaging_zmq.ipc_dir out_sock = ZmqSocket(self.conf, "ipc://%s/zmq_topic_%s" % (ipc_dir, topic), sock_type, bind=True) except RPCException: waiter.send_exception(*sys.exc_info()) return while(True): topic = data[1].bytes topic = 'fanout~' + topic.split('.', 1)[0] topic = '.'.join((topic.split('.', 1)[0], self.conf.oslo_messaging_zmq.host)) reply_topic = "zmq_replies.%s" % conf.oslo_messaging_zmq.host 'topic': reply_topic, "ipc://%s/zmq_topic_zmq_replies.%s" % conf.oslo_messaging_zmq.host), queues = _get_matchmaker(conf).queues(topic) topic = target.topic topic = 'fanout~' + topic elif target.server: topic = '%s.%s' % (topic, target.server) target = target(topic=target.topic.replace('.', '-')) conn.create_consumer('%s.%s' % (target.topic, target.server), listener) conn.create_consumer('%s-%s' % (target.topic, priority), listener)

commit_message:
Reduce global CONF usage in zmq driver

Reduced usage of global CONF object. Implemented a decorator for lazy
options registration. Each essence uses config options is independent
from others. Registered two options groups for zmq driver.

Since this patch the tests require `eventlet`. `eventlet` added to
test-requirements-py3.txt.

Change-Id: I2905cb288617052bf1c039aef000aeeee6468e15
Closes-Bug: #1373382

commit_message:
Auto-delete queues were deleted on RabbitMQ failover

When RPC client starts listening to reply queue and got disconnected from RabbitMQ,
reply queue got deleted because it was marked as auto-delete and no more consumers
were present.

This fix replaces auto-delete with queue 1H expiration. So clients have
up to an hour to reconnect to RaqbbitMQ prior to server's reply gets lost

Change-Id: Ic1a20c309ff90618f715f4034847e6e159c486e8
Closes-Bug: #1349301
