commit_message:
Add API for introspecting VMDKs

This change adds vmdk.py and test_vmdk.py(correspoing unit tests)
to oslo/vmware and tests/ respectively.
vmdk.py has a class API which has the following methods
introspecting VMDKs(monolithicSparse, monolithicFlat,
streamOptimized):

    *get_adapter_type
    *get_disk_type
    *get_virtual_size

Change-Id: I2e9966790b7d0dd9b669aa0c10bea2f3a2c459f7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.vmware refs/changes/31/95231/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2014 VMware, Inc. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import contextlib import logging import urllib2 from oslo.vmware import exceptions LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) class API(object): def get_adapter_type(self, vmdk): """Return string of adapater type defined in VMDK file Currently assuming path and format of VMDK file is valid e.g) no missing fields :param vmdk: file path of VMDK file file path can be local or remote (i.e. with http protocol) """ adapter_type = None def extract_adapter_type(file): for line in file: info = line.split() if info == []: continue if info[0] == 'ddb.adapterType': #info format => ['ddb.adapterType','=',adapter_type] return info[2] if vmdk.startswith(('http:')): with contextlib.closing(urllib2.urlopen(vmdk)) as page: adapter_type = extract_adapter_type(page) else: with open(vmdk, 'r') as f: adapter_type = extract_adapter_type(f) if not adapter_type: excep_msg = _("Could not extract adapter_type from VMDK file.") LOG.error(excep_msg) raise exceptions.VimException(excep_msg) return adapter_type def get_disk_type(self, vmdk): """Return string of disk type defined in VMDK file Currently assuming path and format of VMDK file is valid e.g) no missing fields :param vmdk: file path of VMDK file file path can be local or remote (i.e. with http protocol) """ disk_type = None def extract_disk_type(file): for line in file: info = line.split('=') if info == []: continue if info[0] == 'createType': #info format => ['createTyel', disk_type'\n'] createType_without_newline = info[1][:-1] return createType_without_newline if vmdk.startswith(('http:')): with contextlib.closing(urllib2.urlopen(vmdk)) as page: disk_type = extract_disk_type(page) else: with open(vmdk, 'r') as f: disk_type = extract_disk_type(f) if not disk_type: excep_msg = _("Could not extract disk_type from VMDK file.") LOG.error(excep_msg) raise exceptions.VimException(excep_msg) return disk_type def get_virtual_size(self, vmdk): """Return string of virtual size defined in VMDK file Currently assuming path and format of VMDK file is valid e.g) no missing fields :param vmdk: file path of VMDK file file path can be local or remote (i.e. with http protocol) """ size = None def extract_virtual_size(file): for line in file: if line == '# Extent description\n': # description format => '<accesstype>[space]<size>[space]' description = file.next() size = description.split()[1] return size if vmdk.startswith(('http:')): with contextlib.closing(urllib2.urlopen(vmdk)) as page: size = extract_virtual_size(page) else: with open(vmdk, 'r') as f: size = extract_virtual_size(f) if not size: excep_msg = _("Could not extract virtual size from VMDK file.") LOG.error(excep_msg) raise exceptions.VimException(excep_msg) return size

commit_message:
Traverse children list to check if any worker stop

Currently Neutron server spawns two green threads for api and rpc
job. In _wait_child, both green threads get pid of the stopped
worker from os.waitpid, but if the pid is not in the green thread's
children list, the stopped worker is not restarted.

Considering this two green threads are in the same process, api
green thread may get a pid belonging to a worker forked by rpc
green thread and will not restart the worker. We need to traverse
the children list of each green thread in _wait_child to ensure
stopped worker can be properly recognized.

Change-Id: I056235b11f3e239a8a7e78a507e002978a306b8c
Closes-Bug: #1384580

Fix strings for python3

Use six to detect unicode strings for python2
and python3. Based on a patch in Debian/Ubuntu
by Thomas Goirand.

commit_message:
Make tox use develop mode

Currently running tox fails on a system where pbr isn't installed in
the base-environment.  This is because "python setup.py sdist" isn't
run in the virtualenv and thus the package gets built as
"UNKNOWN-0.0.0.zip" and subsequently fails.

Running tox in develop mode seems to be the standard way things are
done in other parts of the projects.

Also copy in some other standard settings; install_command using pip
(which requires minversion = 1.6) and handing testr args

Change-Id: I9017d0bbc0e606a28b70ca20fff3f58068fc062d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.config refs/changes/19/145119/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: minversion = 1.6 skipsdist = Trueusedevelop = True install_command = pip install -U {opts} {packages} python setup.py testr --coverage --testr-args='{posargs}'
deleted_lines: distribute = False python setup.py testr --coverage

commit_message:
Transfer class LazyPluggable from nova to oslo.utils

Need to transfer code of class LazyPluggable to oslo.utils
because this code copied in different projects. Global
attribute CONF is now transmitted in __init__ function.
Also was written tests for this class.

Change-Id: I63384cfce74a9bcd77e76959dca8be65a8cd1ea0

imported lazily') conf.register_opt(test_backend) module_name = 'tests.test_importutils' from_list = 'tests.test_importutils' _backend = importutils.LazyPluggable(conf, 'foo', config_group=None, bar=module_name) self.assertIs(__import__(module_name, None, None, from_list), _backend._get_backend()) def test_load_lazy_pluggable_with_config_group(self): conf = cfg.ConfigOpts() test_backend = cfg.StrOpt('foo', default='bar', help='This module will be imported lazily') test_group = cfg.OptGroup(name='group', title='Test Options') conf.register_group(test_group) conf.register_opt(test_backend, test_group) module_name = 'tests.test_importutils' from_list = 'tests.test_importutils' _backend = importutils.LazyPluggable(conf, 'foo', config_group='group', bar=module_name) self.assertIs(__import__(module_name, None, None, from_list), _backend._get_backend()) def test_load_lazy_pluggable_when_backend_is_tuple(self): conf = cfg.ConfigOpts() test_backend = cfg.StrOpt('foo', default='bar', help='This module will be imported lazily') conf.register_opt(test_backend) module_name = 'tests.test_importutils' from_list = 'tests.test_importutils' _backend = importutils.LazyPluggable(conf, 'foo', config_group=None, bar=(module_name, from_list)) self.assertIs(__import__(module_name, None, None, from_list), _backend._get_backend()) def test_load_lazy_pluggable_when_backend_tuple_length_is_incorrect(self): conf = cfg.ConfigOpts() test_backend = cfg.StrOpt('foo', default='bar', help='This module will be imported lazily') conf.register_opt(test_backend) module_name = 'tests.test_importutils' _backend = importutils.LazyPluggable(conf, 'foo', config_group=None, bar=tuple(module_name)) self.assertRaises(ValueError, _backend._get_backend) def test_load_lazy_pluggable_raise_of_PluginLoadError(self): conf = cfg.ConfigOpts() test_backend = cfg.StrOpt('foo', default='bar_1', help='This module will be imported lazily') conf.register_opt(test_backend) module_name = 'tests.test_importutils' _backend = importutils.LazyPluggable(conf, 'foo', config_group=None, bar_2=module_name) self.assertRaises(importutils.PluginLoadError, _backend._get_backend) def test_verify_lazyness_itself(self): conf = cfg.ConfigOpts() test_backend = cfg.StrOpt('foo', default='bar', help='This module will be imported lazily') conf.register_opt(test_backend) module_name = 'tests.test_importutils' _backend = importutils.LazyPluggable(conf, 'foo', config_group=None, bar=module_name) self.assertIsNone(_backend._backend)

commit_message:
docs: Add testing howto doc.

This doc goes through a detailed example of setting up DevStack with
OVN.

Change-Id: I16aed1268593293509c8100023d39a6ac42afd7d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-ovn refs/changes/64/179264/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Testing with DevStack ===================== This document describes how to test OpenStack with OVN using DevStack. We will start by describing how to test on a single host. Single Node Test Environment ---------------------------- 1. Create a test system. It's best to use a throwaway dev system for running DevStack. In this example I'm using a Fedora 21 VM with 4 GB of RAM. You should be able to use any distribution that is supported by DevStack. So far, networking-ovn is being tested on Fedora 21 and Ubuntu 14.04. Create a user and grant it sudo access. Install git. 2. Get DevStack and networking-ovn. :: $ git clone http://git.openstack.org/openstack-dev/devstack.git $ git clone http://git.openstack.org/stackforge/networking-ovn.git 3. Configure DevStack to use networking-ovn. networking-ovn comes with a sample DevStack configuration file you can start with. For example, you may want to set some values for the various PASSWORD variables in that file so DevStack doesn't have to prompt you for them. Feel free to edit it if you'd like, but it should work as-is. :: $ cd devstack $ cp ../networking-ovn/devstack/local.conf.sample local.conf 4. Run DevStack. This is going to take a while. It installs a bunch of packages, clones a bunch of git repos, and installs everything from these git repos. :: $ ./stack.sh Default Networks ---------------- .. TODO: Discuss the default networks created by Neutron and how those are reflected in OVN. Booting VMs ----------- .. TODO: Go through detailed instructions for booting some VMs and how the VM's NICs are associated with Neutron ports, OVN, and OVS. Multi-node Testing ------------------ DevStack supports setting up multi-node OpenStack deployments. The networking-ovn devstack integration needs a bit more work before that works, though. Once that work has been completed and tested, this document will be updated to cover a multi-node devstack test environment.

Mixing "str" and "unicode" can lead to a UnicodeDecodeError. We encode unicode
values before using them with text strings.

Change-Id: Ib7fdf60f8369ea9546fcd92f1ac385c777478d10
Closes-Bug: #1428706
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-03-25 16:41:31.000000000', 'files': ['keystoneclient/tests/unit/test_s3_token_middleware.py', 'keystoneclient/middleware/s3_token.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-keystoneclient/commit/b965751ccdd9b4399b8148b1639712bc5577dd12', 'message': 'Prevent a UnicodeDecodeError in the s3token middleware

Mixing "str" and "unicode" can lead to a UnicodeDecodeError. We encode unicode
values before using them with text strings.

The bug occurs if the URL contains a non-ASCII character in the tenant id:
"hho" in "/v1/AUTH_cfa/c/hho" ("/v1/AUTH_cfa/c/h\xc3\xa9ho" in UTF-8) for
example.

The bug occurs on Python 2 in s3_token.py because the tenant id is retrieved
from identity_info['access']['token']['tenant'] and identity_info comes from
resp.json().

The problem is that in Python, the JSON decoder always create Unicode strings.
Example in Python 2:

>>> json.loads('{"key": "value"}') {u'key': u'value'}

There is no issue in Python 3, since all text strings are Unicode.

Change-Id: Ib7fdf60f8369ea9546fcd92f1ac385c777478d10
Closes-Bug: #1428706
'}]
commit_message:
Prevent a UnicodeDecodeError in the s3token middleware

Mixing "str" and "unicode" can lead to a UnicodeDecodeError. We encode unicode
values before using them with text strings.

The bug occurs if the URL contains a non-ASCII character in the tenant id:
"hho" in "/v1/AUTH_cfa/c/hho" ("/v1/AUTH_cfa/c/h\xc3\xa9ho" in UTF-8) for
example.

The bug occurs on Python 2 in s3_token.py because the tenant id is retrieved
from identity_info['access']['token']['tenant'] and identity_info comes from
resp.json().

The problem is that in Python, the JSON decoder always create Unicode strings.
Example in Python 2:

>>> json.loads('{"key": "value"}') {u'key': u'value'}

There is no issue in Python 3, since all text strings are Unicode.

Change-Id: Ib7fdf60f8369ea9546fcd92f1ac385c777478d10
Closes-Bug: #1428706
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-keystoneclient refs/changes/62/161762/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if six.PY2 and isinstance(tenant_to_connect, six.text_type): tenant_to_connect = tenant_to_connect.encode('utf-8')

commit_message:
Update rccut and rcdelivery to match Kilo process

For Kilo we switched to using stable/* instead of proposed/* as the
pre-release branch. Update scripts to match that.

We also stop waiting for tarballs to be built and compare them to
previous branch tarballs -- we can't rely on that test given how much
time it takes to get branch tarballs generated those days.

Change-Id: I46f069ccb5e5a6baa9c768f7d5e1c7d1237e6546

commit_message:
Add option to format release notes for email

Add an option to generate an email message body suitable to be passed to
sendmail or msmtp so it can be sent directly without having to be copied
into another email program.

Bond transactions together to reduce the number of
OVSDB transactions

added_lines: def _set_network_name_command(self, network): return self._ovn.set_lswitch_ext_id( utils.ovn_name(network['id']), ext_id) def _set_network_id_command(self, network): return self._ovn.set_lswitch_ext_id( utils.ovn_name(network['id']), ext_id) with self._ovn.transaction() as txn: txn.add(self._ovn.create_lswitch( utils.ovn_name(network['id']))) txn.add(self._set_network_id_command(network)) txn.add(self._set_network_name_command(network)) self._set_network_name_command(network).execute() def _set_port_name_command(self, port): return self._ovn.set_lport_ext_id(port['id'], ext_id) def _set_from_binding_profile(self, port, txn): txn.add(self._ovn.set_lport_parent_name(port['id'], parent_name)) txn.add(self._ovn.set_lport_tag(port['id'], tag)) with self._ovn.transaction() as txn: txn.add(self._ovn.create_lport(port['id'], utils.ovn_name(port['network_id']))) txn.add(self._ovn.set_lport_mac(port['id'], port['mac_address'])) txn.add(self._set_port_name_command(port)) self._set_from_binding_profile(port, txn) with self._ovn.transaction() as txn: # Neutron allows you to update the MAC address on a port. txn.add(self._ovn.set_lport_mac(port['id'], port['mac_address'])) # Neutron allows you to update the name on a port. txn.add(self._set_port_name_command(port)) self._set_from_binding_profile(port, txn)

commit_message:
Reduce the number of OVSDB transactions

This patch aggregate value creating/settings to
one command in order to reduce OVSDB transactions
and avoid un-needed re-searches for each value setting

Change-Id: Ib96b3f0991092949fa4c0363183ed4951a92c9d9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-ovn refs/changes/40/178540/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def __init__(self, api, name, external_ids, may_exist): self.external_ids = external_ids if self.external_ids is not None: row.external_ids = self.external_ids def __init__(self, api, lport, lswitch, mac, external_ids, parent_name, tag, may_exist): self.lswitch = lswitch self.mac = mac self.external_ids = external_ids if self.mac is not None: port.macs = [self.mac] if self.external_ids is not None: port.external_ids = self.external_ids class SetLogicalPortCommand(BaseCommand): def __init__(self, api, lport, mac, external_ids, parent_name, tag): super(SetLogicalPortCommand, self).__init__(api) self.lport = lport self.mac = mac self.external_ids = external_ids self.parent_name = parent_name self.tag = tag def run_idl(self, txn): try: port = idlutils.row_by_value(self.api.idl, 'Logical_Port', 'name', self.lport) except idlutils.RowNotFound: msg = _("Logical Port %s does not exist") % self.lport LOG.error(msg) raise RuntimeError(msg) if self.parent_name is not None: port.parent_name = self.parent_name if self.tag is not None: port.tag = self.tag if self.mac is not None: port.macs = [self.mac] if self.external_ids is not None: port.external_ids = self.external_ids

commit_message:
ClusterPolicy module for bindings btw the two objects

This is an object to represent the bindings between clusters and
policies. An explicit object representation hopefully can help easy
runtime operation of its fields.

Change-Id: I3b1d07089efd933ac21b0b38a7372b0013a23fe4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/senlin refs/changes/20/179720/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from oslo_log import log as logging from senlin.common import exception from senlin.db import api as db_api LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) # TODO(Qiming): expose configuration options for default values for # policy attachments, i.e. cooldown, priority, level, enabled class ClusterPolicy(object): '''Object representing a binding between a cluster and a policy. This object also records the runtime data of a policy, if any. ''' def __init__(self, cluster_id, policy_id, context=None, **kwargs): self.id = kwargs.get('id', None) self.cluster_id = cluster_id self.policy_id = policy_id self.cooldown = kwargs.get('user', '') self.priority = kwargs.get('project', '') self.level = kwargs.get('domain', '') self.enabled = kwargs.get('enabled', '') self.data = kwargs.get('data', {}) # derived data from binding, put here for convenience self.cluster_name = kwargs.get('cluster_name', '') self.policy_name = kwargs.get('policy_name', '') self.policy_type = kwargs.get('policy_type', '') def store(self, context): '''Store the binding record into database table.''' values = { 'cooldown': self.cooldown, 'prirority': self.priority, 'level': self.level, 'enabled': self.enabled, 'data': self.data, } if self.id: db_api.cluster_policy_update(context, self.cluster_id, self.policy_id, values) else: binding = db_api.cluster_policy_attach(context, self.cluster_id, self.policy_id, values) self.id = binding.id return self.id @classmethod def _from_db_record(cls, context, record): '''Construct a node object from database record. :param context: the context used for DB operations; :param record: a DB node object that contains all fields; ''' kwargs = { 'id': record.id, 'cooldown': record.cooldown, 'priority': record.priority, 'level': record.level, 'enabled': record.enabled, 'data': record.data, # derived data 'cluster_name': record.cluster.name, 'policy_name': record.policy.name, 'policy_type': record.policy.type, } return cls(record.cluster_id, record.policy_id, context=context, **kwargs) @classmethod def load(cls, context, cluster_id, policy_id): '''Retrieve a cluster-policy binding from database.''' binding = db_api.cluster_policy_get(context, cluster_id, policy_id) if binding is None: raise exception.PolicyNotAttached(policy=policy_id, cluster=cluster_id) return cls._from_db_record(context, binding) @classmethod def load_all(cls, context, cluster_id, filters=None, sort_keys=None, sort_dir=None): '''Retrieve all policies attached to a specific cluster.''' bindings = db_api.cluster_policy_get_all(context, cluster_id, filters=filters, sort_keys=sort_keys, sort_dir=sort_dir) return [cls._from_db_record(context, b) for b in bindings] def to_dict(self): binding_dict = { 'id': self.id, 'cluster_id': self.cluster_id, 'policy_id': self.policy_id, 'cooldown': self.cooldown, 'priority': self.priority, 'level': self.level, 'enabled': self.enabled, 'data': self.data, # below are derived data for user's convenience 'cluster_name': self.cluster_name, 'policy_name': self.policy_name, 'policy_type': self.policy_type, } return binding_dict @classmethod def from_dict(cls, **kwargs): return cls(**kwargs)

Unbreak the build_sphinx builder option

We were overriding an option a bit overzealously. If someone provides it
on the command line, honor it.

Closes-Bug: #1447666
Change-Id: Iaef31a198cda4b03a87b12bb9f5c9b67c18f80e0

commit_message:
Don't short circuit when projects fails to clone

This change adds a check to propose_update.sh,
avoiding it to go into fatal error when a project
fails to clone.

Just report the incident and move onto the next
project.

Change-Id: Ib22403f1bd27070b8121a9d79bb95cae409dbe7d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/60/179760/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Don't short circuit when one project fails to clone, just report the # error and move onto the next project. set +e RET=$? set -e if [ "$RET" -ne "0" ] ; then ALL_SUCCESS=1 echo "Error in git clone: Ignoring $PROJECT" continue fi

commit_message:
Adds scenario for network-large-ops

* Spins up multiple instances in one nova call as a regular user.
* VMs are connected to network (unlike test_large_ops)
* Verifies instances are ACTIVE.
* Assigns Floating IP and verifies connectivity to each instance.

Pulls logic for bulk_servers_create from test_large_ops to manager

Adds network-large-ops to tox.ini

Changes required from devstack:

In nova.conf:
quota_instances = -1
quota_cores = -1
quota_ram = -1
quota_floating_ips = -1
quota_fixed_ips = -1
quota_metadata_items = -1
quota_injected_files = -1
quota_injected_file_path_bytes = -1
quota_security_groups = -1
quota_security_group_rules = -1
quota_key_pairs = -1

In neutron.conf:
quota_network = -1
quota_subnet = -1
quota_port = -1
quota_security_group = -1
quota_security_group_rule = -1
quota_vip = -1
quota_pool = -1
quota_member = -1
quota_health_monitors = -1
quota_router = -1
quota_floatingip = -1

In tempest.conf
tenant_network_mask_bit should allow for $large_ops_number IP addresses in
tenant

Change-Id: I5593393dc30262b4b28f4274695d604825d29383

commit_message:
Set USE_CLUSTER variable in devstack

USE_CLUSTER needed to determine which version of the midonet
plugin to load (API-based or cluster-based), is not set correctly
in devstack.

Change-Id: I4e98194b850b683a635703a67aa1a62601c49c79
Fixes: MNP-120

subject: Downcase /etc/hosts entries
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-04-24 11:27:57.000000000', 'files': ['elements/hosts/os-refresh-config/configure.d/51-hosts'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-image-elements/commit/b85d8d69a0fc652f2b7916efa3fb9f042a0f6d56', 'message': 'Downcase /etc/hosts entries

The entries received from Heat are based on Heat names of
OS::Nova::Server resources, which can contain uppercase letters. However
the hostnames set by Nova are lowercase. This can make the actual
hostname differ from entries in /etc/hosts, which can make the output of
`hostname -f` differ from `facter fqdn`, which can cause failed Puppet
runs.

This patch makes sure that the /etc/hosts entries that Heat adds are
lowercase.

Change-Id: Iec5b6450c5730c081c8f2ca4d6c9786b956c87d5
Partial-Bug: #1447497
'}]
commit_message:
Downcase /etc/hosts entries

The entries received from Heat are based on Heat names of
OS::Nova::Server resources, which can contain uppercase letters. However
the hostnames set by Nova are lowercase. This can make the actual
hostname differ from entries in /etc/hosts, which can make the output of
`hostname -f` differ from `facter fqdn`, which can cause failed Puppet
runs.

This patch makes sure that the /etc/hosts entries that Heat adds are
lowercase.

Change-Id: Iec5b6450c5730c081c8f2ca4d6c9786b956c87d5
Partial-Bug: #1447497
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-image-elements refs/changes/77/177177/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ENTRIES=$(os-apply-config --key hosts --type raw --key-default '' | tr '[A-Z]' '[a-z]')
deleted_lines: ENTRIES=$(os-apply-config --key hosts --type raw --key-default '')

Pushing a version through gerrit should also publish version
to pypi.

Pypi project: https://pypi.python.org/pypi?name=networking-hyperv

commit_message:
Adds pypi-jobs to networking-hyperv

Pushing a version through gerrit should also publish version
to pypi.

Pypi project: https://pypi.python.org/pypi?name=networking-hyperv
openstackci is added as admin user.

Change-Id: I0e971bc4c0f770480e98eeff51d8adf7bf3fba3e

commit_message:
Validate cluster attributes

Add validation for cluster attributes. Do it so that it doesn't break
compatibility with current tests. Validate regexpes if they are provided.

Change-Id: I9c1fc04dab45aecf3e32615172654d11844df7c3
Closes-Bug: #1447407

commit_message:
Add support status for current_size ASG attribute

Adds SupportStatus version='2015.1' for `current_size` attribute
of OS::Heat::AutoScalingGroup.

Change-Id: Ib20efc9c8e1cd08fe0b259df381c69ce7f98a41d
Closes-Bug: #1451062

commit_message:
Rename keystoneclient-federation to saml2

Saml2 authentication plugins were initially extracted to the federation
repository, however we don't want to lump all these plugins together as
they may have very different dependencies and jobs.

Rename repo to more accurately reflect contents.

Related governance change is Ia25e14a6afa939590ebba3a91973ceee4a8eaee2

Change-Id: Ie23f0c3a1f3e0a65baabe3dbd19091908da1aba2

commit_message:
Enable tenant/user specific instance filtering

This patch enables tenant and user specific filtering.
Prior to this, one could not filter list of servers on
tenant or user basis.
For example -
nova list --tenant <tenant_id> [--user <user_id>]
This was not giving desirable output.
This patch removes this limitation.
Note in above that currently python-client does not implement
"--user" argument. I will add a patch for that also.
Thus one can filter out servers tenant and user basis.
If you are not passing user info then current context
user will be entertained.
Similarly, If you are not passing tenant info,
this will entertain current context tenant.
Closes-Bug: #1398329
Author: Mh Raies raiesmh08@gmail.com

(cherry picked from commit cf209713dff8bc84e0f251f9f2dc2a2e6fcf0ae0)

Co-Authored-By: Michal Jura mjura@suse.com
Change-Id: I53ca239395b538bc103a8e5cefc728142a034f20

commit_message:
Add experimental Identity v3 jobs to devstack

Identity API v3 jobs use the auth_version=v3
setting in Tempest, which uses v3 auth tokens.

In order to make Devstack use only tokens v3 and
Identity API v3, some work still need to be done.

This change enables an experimental check on
Devstack to be used on the incoming Devstack
patches.

Partially-implements: bp/keystone-v3-jobs

Change-Id: Iba9ed29cbc726c2abdb0a99ec789af949169a920

commit_message:
FirstApp: Move source directory up, rename top-level dir

For the RST guides, we do not need doc/source, since doc is always
empty. Use source directly.

This syncs the setup used here with openstack-manuals.

Rename top-level from openstack-firstapp to firstapp, there's no need
for the long name in this repo.

Change-Id: If4e11a4f90d580876865348e0d88b92cec4b6659

commit_message:
Fix RabbitMQ OCF stop/start actions

W/o this fix, rabbitMQ OCF may hang on the stop or start
as it ignores the stop/wait commands exit code. This is an
issue as it prevents rabbit node from joining the cluster.

The solution is to report generic failure, if corresponding
commands timed out:
* Fix stop_server_process() timeout command exit code check.
* Fix try_to_start_rmq_app() timeout command exit code check.

Closes-bug: #1446190

Change-Id: I8a0ccdde88cbb4c8545427f5bd6bdca6856a4687
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobrelia@mirantis.com>
(cherry picked from commit 1b553e823effcd14d59f42ec36852339d709e7a4)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/36/175836/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: rc=$? rc=$? if [[ $rc != $OCF_SUCCESS ]] ; then ocf_log err "${LH} RMQ-server app cannot be stopped." return $OCF_ERR_GENERIC fi rc=$? if [[ $rc != $OCF_SUCCESS ]] ; then ocf_log err "${LH} RMQ-server app failed to wait for start." return $OCF_ERR_GENERIC fi

commit_message:
Fix RabbitMQ OCF stop/start actions

W/o this fix, rabbitMQ OCF may hang on the stop or start
as it ignores the stop/wait commands exit code. This is an
issue as it prevents rabbit node from joining the cluster.

The solution is to report generic failure, if corresponding
commands timed out:
* Fix stop_server_process() timeout command exit code check.
* Fix try_to_start_rmq_app() timeout command exit code check

Closes-bug: #1446190

Change-Id: I8a0ccdde88cbb4c8545427f5bd6bdca6856a4687
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobrelia@mirantis.com>
(cherry picked from commit 1b553e823effcd14d59f42ec36852339d709e7a4)

added_lines: rc=$? rc=$? if [[ $rc != $OCF_SUCCESS ]] ; then ocf_log err "${LH} RMQ-server app cannot be stopped." return $OCF_ERR_GENERIC fi rc=$? if [[ $rc != $OCF_SUCCESS ]] ; then ocf_log err "${LH} RMQ-server app failed to wait for start." return $OCF_ERR_GENERIC fi

commit_message:
Chnage the default IP_VERSION to 4

DevStack has been set to dual stack by default in Kilo+.
Therefore all tests are failing. Reverting to V4
for integration tests till we fix the templates.

Change-Id: I4a9e4b40d0a1d8dc4231b4331eef82508d0f22a8

commit_message:
Add unit tests for mistral workflow

Improve coverage from 47% to 80%
Change-Id: Ia0d43938978c4aa62e9a05570e1af028de484d10
Closes-Bug: #1449808
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/62/179162/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: workflow_template_update_replace = """workflow_template_update = """ heat_template_version: 2013-05-23 resources: workflow: type: OS::Mistral::Workflow properties: type: direct description: just testing workflow resource tasks: - name: hello action: std.echo output='Good evening!' publish: result: <% $.hello %> """ self.mistral = mock.Mock() self.patchobject(workflow.Workflow, 'mistral', return_value=self.mistral) def test_update_replace(self): t = template_format.parse(workflow_template_update_replace) def test_update(self): wf = self._create_resource('workflow', self.rsrc_defn, self.stack) t = template_format.parse(workflow_template_update) rsrc_defns = template.Template(t).resource_definitions(self.stack) new_wf = rsrc_defns['workflow'] self.mistral.workflows.update.return_value = [ FakeWorkflow('test_stack-workflow-b5fiekfci3yc')] scheduler.TaskRunner(wf.update, new_wf)() self.mistral.workflows.update.assert_called_once() self.assertEqual((wf.UPDATE, wf.COMPLETE), wf.state) def test_update_failed(self): wf = self._create_resource('workflow', self.rsrc_defn, self.stack) t = template_format.parse(workflow_template_update) rsrc_defns = template.Template(t).resource_definitions(self.stack) new_wf = rsrc_defns['workflow'] self.mistral.workflows.update.side_effect = Exception('boom!') self.assertRaises(exception.ResourceFailure, scheduler.TaskRunner(wf.update, new_wf)) self.assertEqual((wf.UPDATE, wf.FAILED), wf.state) def test_signal_failed(self): tmpl = template_format.parse(workflow_template_full) stack = utils.parse_stack(tmpl) rsrc_defns = stack.t.resource_definitions(stack)['create_vm'] wf = workflow.Workflow('create_vm', rsrc_defns, stack) self.mistral.workflows.create.return_value = [ FakeWorkflow('create_vm')] scheduler.TaskRunner(wf.create)() details = {'input': {'flavor': '3'}} self.mistral.executions.create.side_effect = Exception('boom!') err = self.assertRaises(exception.ResourceFailure, scheduler.TaskRunner(wf.signal, details)) self.assertEqual('Exception: boom!', six.text_type(err)) def test_signal_wrong_input_and_params_type(self): tmpl = template_format.parse(workflow_template_full) stack = utils.parse_stack(tmpl) rsrc_defns = stack.t.resource_definitions(stack)['create_vm'] wf = workflow.Workflow('create_vm', rsrc_defns, stack) self.mistral.workflows.create.return_value = [ FakeWorkflow('create_vm')] scheduler.TaskRunner(wf.create)() details = {'input': '3'} err = self.assertRaises(exception.ResourceFailure, scheduler.TaskRunner(wf.signal, details)) error_message = ("StackValidationFailed: Signal data error : Input in" " signal data must be a map, find a <type 'str'>") self.assertEqual(error_message, six.text_type(err)) details = {'params': '3'} err = self.assertRaises(exception.ResourceFailure, scheduler.TaskRunner(wf.signal, details)) error_message = ("StackValidationFailed: Signal data error : Params " "must be a map, find a <type 'str'>") self.assertEqual(error_message, six.text_type(err)) def test_signal_wrong_input_key(self): tmpl = template_format.parse(workflow_template_full) stack = utils.parse_stack(tmpl) rsrc_defns = stack.t.resource_definitions(stack)['create_vm'] wf = workflow.Workflow('create_vm', rsrc_defns, stack) self.mistral.workflows.create.return_value = [ FakeWorkflow('create_vm')] scheduler.TaskRunner(wf.create)() details = {'input': {'1': '3'}} err = self.assertRaises(exception.ResourceFailure, scheduler.TaskRunner(wf.signal, details)) error_message = ("StackValidationFailed: Signal data error :" " Unknown input 1") self.assertEqual(error_message, six.text_type(err)) def test_signal_and_delete_with_executions(self): tmpl = template_format.parse(workflow_template_full) stack = utils.parse_stack(tmpl) rsrc_defns = stack.t.resource_definitions(stack)['create_vm'] wf = workflow.Workflow('create_vm', rsrc_defns, stack) self.mistral.workflows.create.return_value = [ FakeWorkflow('create_vm')] scheduler.TaskRunner(wf.create)() details = {'input': {'flavor': '3'}} execution = mock.Mock() execution.id = '12345' self.mistral.executions.create.return_value = execution scheduler.TaskRunner(wf.signal, details)() self.assertEqual({'executions': '12345'}, wf.data()) scheduler.TaskRunner(wf.delete)() self.assertEqual(1, self.mistral.executions.delete.call_count) self.assertEqual((wf.DELETE, wf.COMPLETE), wf.state)

Refactored run_server script

Used the updated version of run_server script
from python-fuelclient.

Closes-bug: #1446211
Change-Id: I2c8538fa6e3854f2c33434a1b08d366121cc55b1

added_lines: NAILGUN_ROOT=$ROOT/nailgunNAILGUN_CHECK_PATH=${NAILGUN_CHECK_PATH:-"/api/version"} NAILGUN_START_MAX_WAIT_TIME=${NAILGUN_START_MAX_WAIT_TIME:-10} run_server $SERVER_PORT $server_log $config || \ SERVER_PORT=$SERVER_PORT \ ${CASPERJS} test --includes="$TESTS_DIR/helpers.js" --fail-fast "$testcase" if [ $? -ne 0 ]; then kill $pid wait $pid 2> /dev/null # Sends SIGING to running Nailgun kill_server() { # kill old server instance if exists local pid=$(lsof -ti tcp:$NAILGUN_PORT) if [[ -n "$pid" ]]; then kill $pid sleep $NAILGUN_START_MAX_WAIT_TIME fi } # $1 -- path to log file # $2 -- path to the server configrun_server() { local server_port=$1 local server_log=$2 local server_config=$3 local run_server_cmd="\ python manage.py run \ --port=$server_port \ --config=$server_config \ --fake-tasks \ --fake-tasks-tick-count=80 \ --fake-tasks-tick-interval=1" kill_server # run new server instance pushd $NAILGUN_ROOT > /dev/null tox -evenv -- $run_server_cmd >> $server_log 2>&1 & popd > /dev/null # wait for server availability which curl > /dev/null if [[ $? -eq 0 ]]; then local num_retries=$((NAILGUN_START_MAX_WAIT_TIME * 10)) local check_url="http://0.0.0.0:"$server_port$NAILGUN_CHECK_PATH local i=0 while true; do # Fail if number of retries exeeded if [[ $i -gt $((num_retries + 1)) ]]; then return 1; fi local http_code=$(curl -s -w %{http_code} -o /dev/null $check_url) if [[ "$http_code" = "200" ]]; then return 0; fi sleep 0.1 i=$((i + 1)) done else sleep $NAILGUN_START_MAX_WAIT_TIME lsof -ti tcp:$server_port return $? fi
deleted_lines: NAILGUN_CHECK_URL=${NAILGUN_CHECK_URL:-"http://0.0.0.0:$NAILGUN_PORT/api/version"} NAILGUN_START_MAX_WAIT_TIME=${NAILGUN_START_MAX_WAIT_TIME:-5} pid=`run_server $SERVER_PORT $server_log $config` || \ if [ "$pid" -ne "0" ]; then SERVER_PORT=$SERVER_PORT \ ${CASPERJS} test --includes="$TESTS_DIR/helpers.js" --fail-fast "$testcase" if [ $? -ne 0 ]; then result=1 break fi kill $pid wait $pid 2> /dev/null else cat $server_log# $1 -- server port # $2 -- path to log file # $3 -- path to the server configfunction run_server { local SERVER_PORT=$1 local SERVER_LOG=$2 local SERVER_SETTINGS=$3 local RUN_SERVER="\ python manage.py run \ --port=$SERVER_PORT \ --config=$SERVER_SETTINGS \ --fake-tasks \ --fake-tasks-tick-count=80 \ --fake-tasks-tick-interval=1" pushd $ROOT/nailgun >> /dev/null # kill old server instance if exists local pid=`lsof -ti tcp:$SERVER_PORT` if [ -n "$pid" ]; then kill $pid sleep 5 fi # run new server instance tox -evenv -- $RUN_SERVER >> $SERVER_LOG 2>&1 & # wait for server availability which curl > /dev/null ret=$? if [ $ret -eq 0 ]; then local num_retries=$[$NAILGUN_START_MAX_WAIT_TIME * 10] for i in $(seq 1 $num_retries); do local http_code=`curl -s -w %{http_code} -o /dev/null $NAILGUN_CHECK_URL` if [ "$http_code" == "200" ]; then break; fi sleep 0.1 done else sleep 5 fi popd >> /dev/null pid=`lsof -ti tcp:$SERVER_PORT` local nailgun_launched=$? echo $pid return $nailgun_launched

commit_message:
Puppet/Beaker: drop puppet-{gnocchi,tuskar}

For now, Gnocchi and Tuskar are not packaged in Ubuntu so there is no
way to test the modules with Beaker Rspec.
Until we have the packages, let's drop the useless jobs from the CI.

Change-Id: I895e58d0ea1e8e2c61086a1e0024c411e31a9e63

commit_message:
Remove mention of anti-virus scan

Index page mentioned binary assets were being
scanned for viruses - this is not being practiced
consistently, and should not be mentioned. Removing
for now, and will eventually be replaced with
legal disclaimer indicating downloader is responsible
for determining safety and suitability of all assets.

Change-Id: I78693a6fe94e9173840e688e5b737c0cb78ab950
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/app-catalog refs/changes/27/179527/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: Binary assets are stored in a file-based CDN. Binary assets (Murano zip files and Glance images) are scanned for viruses/malware with Symantec Endpoint Protection for Linux before being added to the catalog.

commit_message:
Added field 'data' to cluster-policy bindings table

This table will be used by a policy to record per-binding data. Sample
use case include -- a policy that requires monitoring records alarm
resource IDs here for their lifecycle management; a load-balancing
policy records the resource of LB pool resource created.

Change-Id: I0ba28bb5cecbc95e5a33032dff9ce30618249ec5

commit_message:
Allow changing project-id and user-id by alarm-threshold-update

Ceilometer alarm-threshold-update should support updating
project-id and user-id, but the update function was silently
ignoring changes of these options.

Change-Id: I33231bff44b90f3c58e5ef1646349b6dc63a3ce7
Closes-Bug: 1395932
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-ceilometerclient refs/changes/00/174400/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: CREATION_ATTRIBUTES = UPDATABLE_ATTRIBUTES + ['project_id', 'user_id', 'time_constraints']

commit_message:
Change log level from INFO to DEBUG

For the method level logs, change the log level from INFO to
DEBUG for consistency and to also conform to the OpenStack logging
policy.

Change-Id: Ie8b621e8799da1b1dde600857c8f27b276826bea
Implements: MNP-119

commit_message:
Add image name support when create a baymodel

Currently, if we create a baymodel and pass an image name as parameter,
an image not found exception would be raised.

This patch add image name support when create a baymodel

Closes-Bug: #1448952

Change-Id: If8b41eacccf0880908dafebb3e86e374399c0bef

commit_message:
Minor tweaking to cluster update flow

This tweak tried avoid using new temp variables for no good. It also
moves the intialization 'inputs' dict closer to where it is used.

Change-Id: I0ca5af71a1a5d8d44943de23532daebe3549cf44

commit_message:
Import positional decorator used by keystoneclient

The positional decorator provides a way to ensure that certain arguments
are passed as kwargs when specified. This provides some great advantages
in maintaining backwards compatibility as you can add new positional
arguments in front of existing keyword arguments, or rearrange existing
keyword arguments.

Change-Id: I7f5b998c73884e590ab2e290fcdd84c006e1452c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.utils refs/changes/18/138218/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import inspect import functools import logging _LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) class positional(object): """A decorator which enforces only some args may be passed positionally. This idea and some of the code was taken from the oauth2 client of the google-api client. This decorator makes it easy to support Python 3 style key-word only parameters. For example, in Python 3 it is possible to write:: def fn(pos1, *, kwonly1, kwonly2=None): ... All named parameters after * must be a keyword:: fn(10, 'kw1', 'kw2') # Raises exception. fn(10, kwonly1='kw1', kwonly2='kw2') # Ok. To replicate this behaviour with the positional decorator you simply specify how many arguments may be passed positionally. To replicate the example above:: @positional(1) def fn(pos1, kwonly1=None, kwonly2=None): ... If no default value is provided to a keyword argument, it becomes a required keyword argument:: @positional(0) def fn(required_kw): ... This must be called with the keyword parameter:: fn() # Raises exception. fn(10) # Raises exception. fn(required_kw=10) # Ok. When defining instance or class methods always remember that in python the first positional argument passed is always the instance so you will need to account for `self` and `cls`:: class MyClass(object): @positional(2) def my_method(self, pos1, kwonly1=None): ... @classmethod @positional(2) def my_method(cls, pos1, kwonly1=None): ... If you would prefer not to account for `self` and `cls` you can use the `method` and `classmethod` helpers which do not consider the initial positional argument. So the following class is exactly the same as the one above:: class MyClass(object): @positional.method(1) def my_method(self, pos1, kwonly1=None): ... @positional.classmethod(1) def my_method(cls, pos1, kwonly1=None): ... If a value isn't provided to the decorator then it will enforce that every variable without a default value will be required to be a kwarg:: @positional() def fn(pos1, kwonly1=None): ... fn(10) # Ok. fn(10, 20) # Raises exception. fn(10, kwonly1=20) # Ok. This behaviour will work with the `positional.method` and `positional.classmethod` helper functions as well:: class MyClass(object): @positional.classmethod() def my_method(cls, pos1, kwonly1=None): ... MyClass.my_method(10) # Ok. MyClass.my_method(10, 20) # Raises exception. MyClass.my_method(10, kwonly1=20) # Ok. For compatibility reasons you may wish to not always raise an exception so a WARN mode is available. Rather than raise an exception a warning message will be logged:: @positional(1, enforcement=positional.WARN): def fn(pos1, kwonly=1): ... Available modes are: - positional.EXCEPT - the default, raise an exception. - positional.WARN - log a warning on mistake. """ EXCEPT = 'except' WARN = 'warn' def __init__(self, max_positional_args=None, enforcement=EXCEPT): self._max_positional_args = max_positional_args self._enforcement = enforcement @classmethod def method(cls, max_positional_args=None, enforcement=EXCEPT): if max_positional_args is not None: max_positional_args += 1 def f(func): return cls(max_positional_args, enforcement)(func) return f @classmethod def classmethod(cls, *args, **kwargs): def f(func): return classmethod(cls.method(*args, **kwargs)(func)) return f def __call__(self, func): if self._max_positional_args is None: spec = inspect.getargspec(func) self._max_positional_args = len(spec.args) - len(spec.defaults) plural = '' if self._max_positional_args == 1 else 's' @functools.wraps(func) def inner(*args, **kwargs): if len(args) > self._max_positional_args: message = ('%(name)s takes at most %(max)d positional ' 'argument%(plural)s (%(given)d given)' % {'name': func.__name__, 'max': self._max_positional_args, 'given': len(args), 'plural': plural}) if self._enforcement == self.EXCEPT: raise TypeError(message) elif self._enforcement == self.WARN: _LOG.warn(message) return func(*args, **kwargs) return inner

commit_message:
Adds Neutron networking to compose/README

Previously, the readme only contained instructions for configuring
nova networking. This patch adds instructions for downloading and
creating a cirros Glance image and neutron networking.

Change-Id: I4aba32baf3e270bb9aa16fde068d99223e75ef66
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/37/176037/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # # Download and create the Glance cirros test image: # curl -L -O http://download.cirros-cloud.net/0.3.3/cirros-0.3.3-x86_64-disk.img # glance image-create --name cirros --is-public=true --disk-format=qcow2 --container-format=bare < cirros-0.3.3-x86_64-disk.img # # If using neutron networking (i.e. NETWORK_MANAGER=neutron) # Note: Replace <$PARAMETER> parameters with settings applicable to your environment. # neutron net-create public --router:external True --provider:physical_network physnet1 --provider:network_type flat # neutron subnet-create --name public-subnet --disable-dhcp --allocation-pool start=<$FLOATING_IP_START>,end=<$FLOATING_IP_STOP> public <$FLOATING_IP_NETWORK>/<$FLOATING_IP_NETMASK> --gateway <$FLOATING_IP_NET_GATEWAY> # neutron net-create tenant-network --provider:network_type vxlan --provider:segmentation_id 10 # neutron subnet-create tenant-network --name tenant-subnet --gateway <$TENANT_NET_GATEWAY> <$TENANT_NETWORK>/<$TENANT_NETMASK> # neutron router-create tenant-router # neutron router-interface-add tenant-router tenant-subnet # neutron router-gateway-set tenant-router public # # Create security group rules for icmp and ssh # neutron security-group-rule-create default --direction ingress --ethertype IPv4 --protocol icmp --remote-ip-prefix 0.0.0.0/0 # neutron security-group-rule-create default --direction ingress --ethertype IPv4 --protocol tcp --port-range-min 22 --port-range-max 22 --remote-ip-prefix 0.0.0.0/0 # # Boot your Nova instance. You can obtain <$TENANT_NETWORK_ID> from the neutron net-list command # nova boot --flavor m1.tiny --image cirros --nic net-id=<$TENANT_NETWORK_ID> # # If using nova networking (i.e. NETWORK_MANAGER=nova)

commit_message:
Import subprocess in cache devstack element

Change fd9c80208c00021a49df6907973bbbb3fa242069 inadvertently
removed the subprocess import from 55-cache-devstack-repos even
though it was used in a function defined within that element, unlike
in its snapshot prep script counterpart. Readd it so that this
element works again.

Change-Id: I954a1e7e99af96b08e0a59e99e513902731fd773
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/88/179688/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add /usr/local/bin to exec_dirs in rootwrap.conf

devstack installs neutron utilities into /usr/local/bin such as
neutron-keepalived-state-change and neutron-ns-metadata-proxy.
In stead of adding individual filters to allow them to run from that
directory, this patch adds /usr/local/bin into exec_dirs.

Please also refer to I3abd1c173121dc8abb5738d1879db8ac9a98b690 for
discussion on the approach to fix the bug.

Change-Id: Iade8b5b09bb53018485c85f8372fb94dbc2ad2da
Closes-Bug: 1435971
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/41/176041/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: sudo sed -e 's:^exec_dirs=\(.*\)$:exec_dirs=\1,/usr/local/bin:' -i $Q_RR_CONF_FILE

commit_message:
Revised cluster-data module

ClusteData class now supports validation of parameters for
cluster_create and cluster_update operations.

Change-Id: If77c3d749e140ebc239896029938a5c3bf79c5fa
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/senlin refs/changes/56/179556/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.name = data.get(consts.CLUSTER_NAME, None) self.profile = data.get(consts.CLUSTER_PROFILE, None) self.parent = data.get(consts.CLUSTER_PARENT, None) self.tags = data.get(consts.CLUSTER_TAGS, None) self.desired_capacity = data.get(consts.CLUSTER_DESIRED_CAPACITY, None) self.min_size = data.get(consts.CLUSTER_MIN_SIZE, None) self.max_size = data.get(consts.CLUSTER_MAX_SIZE, None) self.timeout = data.get(consts.CLUSTER_TIMEOUT, cfg.CONF.default_action_timeout) def _enforce_data_types(self): if self.desired_capacity is not None: self.desired_capacity = utils.parse_int_param( consts.CLUSTER_DESIRED_CAPACITY, self.desired_capacity, allow_zero=True) if self.min_size is not None: self.min_size = utils.parse_int_param( consts.CLUSTER_MIN_SIZE, self.min_size, allow_zero=True) if self.max_size is not None: self.max_size = utils.parse_int_param( consts.CLUSTER_MAX_SIZE, self.max_size, allow_zero=True, allow_negative=True) if self.timeout is not None: self.timeout = utils.parse_int_param( consts.CLUSTER_TIMEOUT, self.timeout, allow_zero=True) def validate_for_create(self): self._enforce_data_types() if self.name is None: if self.desired_capacity is None: raise exc.HTTPBadRequest(_("No cluster desired capacity " "provided.")) if self.profile is None: if self.min_size is not None and self.min_size > self.desired_capacity: msg = _("Cluster min_size, if specified, must be less than or " "equal to its desired capacity.") raise exc.HTTPBadRequest(msg) if self.max_size is not None and self.max_size >= 0: if self.max_size < self.desired_capacity: msg = _("Cluster max_size, if specified, must be greater than " "or equal to its desired capacity. Setting max_size " "to -1 means no upper limit on cluster size.") raise exc.HTTPBadRequest(msg) def validate_for_update(self): self._enforce_data_types() if self.min_size is not None and self.desired_capacity is not None: if self.min_size > self.desired_capacity: msg = _("Cluster min_size, if specified, must be less than" " or equal to its desired capacity.") raise exc.HTTPBadRequest(msg) if self.max_size is not None and self.desired_capacity is not None: if self.max_size >= 0 and self.max_size < self.desired_capacity: msg = _("Cluster max_size, if specified, must be greater than " "or equal to its desired capacity. Setting max_size " "to -1 means no upper limit on cluster size.") raise exc.HTTPBadRequest(msg) # The following checking is necessary because desired_capacity may # be not specified in an update request if self.min_size is not None and self.max_size is not None: if self.max_size >= 0 and self.max_size < self.min_size: msg = _("Cluster max_size, if specified, must be greater than " "or equal to its min_size. Setting max_size to -1 " "means no upper limit on cluster size.") raise exc.HTTPBadRequest(msg) data.validate_for_create() cluster = self.rpc_client.cluster_create( req.context, data.name, data.desired_capacity, data.profile, data.min_size, data.max_size, data.parent, data.tags, data.timeout) data = ClusterData(cluster_data) data.validate_for_update() self.rpc_client.cluster_update( req.context, cluster_id, data.name, data.desired_capacity, data.profile, data.min_size, data.max_size, data.parent, data.tags, data.timeout)
deleted_lines: self.data = data def name(self): if consts.CLUSTER_NAME not in self.data: return self.data[consts.CLUSTER_NAME] def desired_capacity(self): if consts.CLUSTER_DESIRED_CAPACITY not in self.data: raise exc.HTTPBadRequest(_("No cluster desired " "capacity provided.")) return self.data.get(consts.CLUSTER_DESIRED_CAPACITY, None) def min_size(self): return self.data.get(consts.CLUSTER_MIN_SIZE, None) def max_size(self): return self.data.get(consts.CLUSTER_MAX_SIZE, None) def profile(self): if consts.CLUSTER_PROFILE not in self.data: return self.data[consts.CLUSTER_PROFILE] def parent(self): return self.data.get(consts.CLUSTER_PARENT, None) def tags(self): return self.data.get(consts.CLUSTER_TAGS, None) def timeout(self): return self.data.get(consts.CLUSTER_TIMEOUT, cfg.CONF.default_action_timeout) cluster = self.rpc_client.cluster_create(req.context, data.name(), data.desired_capacity(), data.profile(), data.min_size(), data.max_size(), data.parent(), data.tags(), data.timeout()) min_size = cluster_data.get(consts.CLUSTER_MIN_SIZE) max_size = cluster_data.get(consts.CLUSTER_MAX_SIZE) desired_capacity = cluster_data.get(consts.CLUSTER_DESIRED_CAPACITY) name = cluster_data.get(consts.CLUSTER_NAME) profile_id = cluster_data.get(consts.CLUSTER_PROFILE) parent = cluster_data.get(consts.CLUSTER_PARENT) tags = cluster_data.get(consts.CLUSTER_TAGS) timeout = cluster_data.get(consts.CLUSTER_TIMEOUT) if timeout is not None: timeout = utils.parse_int_param(consts.CLUSTER_TIMEOUT, timeout) self.rpc_client.cluster_update(req.context, cluster_id, name, desired_capacity, profile_id, min_size, max_size, parent, tags, timeout)

commit_message:
Revised cluster-update action implementation

There were many corner cases not checked in previous prototype. This
patch attempts to fix them.

Change-Id: Ib721060a1cde98a8585e74158af8f826b0305119
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/senlin refs/changes/19/179619/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def do_update(self, context, **kwargs): This method is intended to be called only from an action. kwargs['status_reason'] = 'Updating in progress' kwargs['status'] = self.UPDATING kwargs['updated_time'] = datetime.datetime.utcnow() db_api.cluster_update(context, self.id, kwargs) # TODO(anyone): generate event record
deleted_lines: from senlin.common.i18n import _LW def _validate_size(self, context, min_size=None, max_size=None, desired_capacity=None, update=False): res = False if min_size is None: min_size = self.min_size if max_size is None: max_size = self.max_size if desired_capacity is None: desired_capacity = self.desired_capacity if min_size > max_size: res = False elif desired_capacity < min_size: res = False elif max_size != 0 and desired_capacity > max_size: res = False else: res = True if update: self.min_size = min_size self.max_size = max_size self.desired_capacity = desired_capacity self.store(context) return res if not self._validate_size(context): LOG.error(_LE('Cluster size validation failed')) return False # self.set_status(context, self.DELETED) def do_update(self, context, desired_capacity, new_profile_id, min_size, max_size, **kwargs): Check size properties and profile and set cluster status to UPDATING. # Check whether size related updating is sanity if not self._validate_size(context, min_size, max_size, desired_capacity, update=True): msg = _LW('Cluster cannot be updated since size validation failed' ': min_size %(min)s, max_size %(max)s, desired_capacity' ' %(des)s') % {'min': min_size, 'max': max_size, 'des': desired_capacity} LOG.warning(msg) return False # Profile type checking is done here because the do_update logic can # be triggered from API or Webhook if not new_profile_id: raise exception.ProfileNotSpecified() if new_profile_id == self.profile_id: return True new_profile = db_api.profile_get(context, new_profile_id) if not new_profile: event_mod.warning(context, self, 'update', _LW('Cluster cannot be updated to a profile ' 'that does not exists')) return False # Check if profile types match old_profile = db_api.profile_get(context, self.profile_id) if old_profile.type != new_profile.type: event_mod.warning(context, self, 'update', _LW('Cluster cannot be updated to a different ' 'profile type (%(oldt)s->%(newt)s)') % { 'oldt': old_profile.type, 'newt': new_profile.type}) return False self.set_status(context, self.UPDATING, reason='Updating in progress')

commit_message:
Revised cluster-update implementation

We now allow min_size and max_size to be updated. So, the code must
be generic and flexible to support different combinations of update
parameters. This patch revised the cluster-update api implementation
which will be followed by a revision at cluster-action level.

Change-Id: I3718c1ead517ad719a34d83ffc0c4a4c6a49b5fb

commit_message:
Add min_size and max_size properties to Cluster

Two new properties are added to cluster: min_size and max_size.
This patch provides related support from client side. Now user
can specify the min and max size of cluster when creating it.

Change-Id: I72869259993ec8a8697eba45c12bf6ba9d408292
Implements: blueprint add-size-limitation-properties-to-cluster

commit_message:
log request id mappings from cinder

This nova-specs is part of a larger effort to log request ID mappings
across service boundaries to allow for easier debugging.

Change-Id: I3ad3cc698b9c76c0c2f0f30ffa64978d9cb36de0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/58/154358/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =================================== log request id mappings from cinder =================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/log-request-id-mappings This nova-specs is part of a larger effort to log request ID mappings across service boundaries to help operators/developers to analyse logs effectively. Whenever a service makes a call to another service it will log both the, calling service request id and called service request id in the same log message. Problem description =================== Each OpenStack service sends a request ID header with HTTP responses. This request ID can be useful for tracking down problems in the services. However, when operation crosses service boundaries, this tracking can become difficult, as each service has its own request ID. This becomes especially problematic when requests are coming in parallel. For example, nova will call to cinder for attaching volume, but that cinder service may be handling several other requests at the same time. By logging a mapping of nova's request ID and cinder's request ID on the same log line, user can easily find the cinder request ID that is related to his nova request in the nova service (e.g. n-cpu, n-api) logs. That cinder request ID can then be searched in cinder's logs. It will help operators/developers to analyse logs effectively. Use Cases --------- As a developer or end user, I want to investigate failed operations using the request ID returned after running a command. Project Priority ---------------- None Proposed change =============== Currently work is in progress [1] to return response headers and body from cinder-client. Cinder-client will return tuple containing header and body. Add support to check type of response returned by cinder-client in nova. If type of response is tuple then it will contain body and 'x-openstack-request-id' which is returned by cinder. This request-id is used to log the mapping of request IDs between nova and cinder. Format of tuple returned by cinder-client: tuple(headers<structures.CaseInsensitiveDict>, body<volume/snapshot object>) If the response returned by cinder is not of type tuple, then this response will be used as it is. The checking of cinder-client return format type is useful for backward compatibility. Following is the code snippet how tuple and non tuple response from cinder-client is checked. .. code:: python response = getattr(client.volumes, method)(*args, **kwargs) if isinstance(response, tuple): # Unpacking response tuple headers, response = response # Response is already returned as a tuple object with old # cinder-client for volume actions e.g. attach, detach etc., # For backward compatibility we need to add an extra condition # to check if first index of tuple is a CaseInsensitiveDict(with # latest cinder-client) or a response object(with old cinder- # client) before logging the mappings. if (isinstance(headers, structures.CaseInsensitiveDict) and 'x-openstack-request-id' in headers): utils.link_request_ids( context, context.request_id, target_id=headers['x-openstack-request-id'], target_name="cinder") return response Note: For volume actions e.g. attach, detach etc., current cinder-client returns response as a tuple containing response object and body. For backward compatibility we need to add an extra condition to check if response in a tuple is a CaseInsensitiveDict(with latest cinder-client) and contains 'x-openstack-request-id' or a response object (with old cinder-client) before logging the request id. [1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/132161/ (cinder-spec) Alternatives ------------ Include the request-id in the HTTP header and use that request-id in subsequent request related to other components like cinder, glance, nova etc., such that the receiving components can use that request id instead of generating its own. Disadvantage: Malicious user can send multiple HTTP requests using same request-id. To distinguish request-ids are unique, services will need to persists request-ids and check for it's duplicity adding performance burden. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: abhijeet-malawade(abhijeet.malawade@nttdata.com) Other contributors: None Reviewers --------- Core reviewer(s): None Other reviewer(s): None Work Items ---------- * Extract response from cinder, check whether it contains x-openstack-request-id and add mapping of nova and cinder request ids in the log message. Dependencies ============ * https://review.openstack.org/#/c/132161/ (cinder-spec) Testing ======= None Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== Log Request ID Mappings https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/log-request-id-mappings Discussions on mailing list and weekly meeting [0] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2014-December/052822.html [1] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/cinder/2014/cinder.2014-12-17-16.00.log.html

commit_message:
Nic bonding support for SRIOV ports

We want to enchance Nova to be able to bond SR-IOV ports to provide HA.
First of all we need to create a mechanism which can land VFs to the different
PFs if it's needed. Next step will be create a Neutron call to hold number of
VFs we need for it.

Change-Id: I7e790b2dc33a170008283ff6bc2e6e17b09bbddb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/60/151260/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Nic bonding support for SRIOV ports ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/libvirt-sriov-nic-bonding We want to enchance Nova to be able to bond SR-IOV ports to provide HA. First of all we need to create a mechanism which can land VFs to the different PFs if it's needed. Next step will be create a Neutron call to hold number of VFs we need for it. Problem description =================== Now we use queue based selection of VFs, in most cases it's guarantee that all VFs from one request will land on the same PF, and we can't do anything with this. Use Cases ---------- We need to build a failover connection to the node. So, if VFs goes to different PFs we will be save in case one of PFs switchover. Project Priority ----------------- Does not directly address listed Kilo priorities. Proposed change =============== Proposed change is triple: * First of all we want to introduce new Neutron port attribute called binding:dev_group. We will use it to define VF/PF placement * Extend PCI API calls to compute service to allocate VF to different PFs. Exception will be raised in case we have less PFs than needed * The same change to scheduller calls. Alternatives ------------ We can find another way to mark in which case we should land VFs to different PFs. May be some policy changes can be provided. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- User will be provided ability to manipulate VF allocation. Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Przemyslaw Czesnowicz <pczesno> Other contributors: Roman Bogorodskiy <novel> Nikolay Starodubtsev <starodubcevna> Work Items ---------- * Implement PCI logic to allocate VFs to different devices built on binding:dev_group parameter. * Implement scheduller logic to sort VF to different PF. * Implement logic to bond VFs as requested Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= The changes to the selection logic are testable through unit testing, as is the extension to the PCI request API. Integration and system testing will require 3rd party CI as it will require specific hardware configurations to properly test. Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== None

commit_message:
Add a new libvirt volume driver for Huawei SDSHypervisor

Add a new volume driver in nova/virt/libvirt/volume.py file to realize
attach/detach volume to qemu-kvm instance, and realize abstract volume dirver
methods:
* connect_volume
* disconnect_volume

Change-Id: I1d18fda62b77c5f46eed174fc0699d8bbe14fe92
Blueprint: huawei-sdshypervisor-volume-driver
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/19/130919/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================================== New libvirt volume driver for Huawei SDSHypervisor ================================================== Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/huawei-sdshypervisor-volume-driver Huawei SDSHypervisor is a storage virtualization solution, is a software running in host, just focus on the data plane, the goal is to facilitate the reuse of customer's existing old and low-end devices. SDSHypervisor does not interact with the storage device in control plane, such as create volume, create snapshot, do not need third-party device manufacturers to develop any driver. Administrator just attaches Lun to the hypervisor node as hypervisor storage entity and hypervisor will provide virtual volume based user's QoS and patch advance feature to these Lun such as snapshot, link clone, cache, thin provision and so on. Huawei SDSHypervisor cinder driver has been merged into cinder in this url https://review.openstack.org/#/c/101688/ The purpose of this blue print is to add a new libvirt volume driver for Huawei SDSHypervisor. Problem description =================== Currently, user can access Huawei SDShypervisor by Openstack Cinder, but can't attach volume from SDSHypervisor to nova instance. Project Priority ----------------- None Proposed change =============== SDShypervisor data panel using private Key Value protocal, so we also add a new libvirt volume driver to realize attach/detach volume. The following diagram shows the command and data paths. ```` +------------------+ +------------------+ | | | | | Nova + | Rest API | Cinder + | | Nova compute | -------------- | Cinder Volume | | (qeumu-kvm) | | | | | | | +------------------+ +------------------+ | | | | | | | | | | | | +-----------------------+ +-----------------------+ +-----------------------+ | | | | | | | | | | | | | SDShypervisor | | SDShypervisor | | SDShypervisor Driver | | libvirt volume driver | | connector | | | | | | | | | +-----------------------+ +-----------------------+ +-----------------------+ | | | | | | | | | CLI CLI Socket API | | | | | | | | | +--------------------------------------+ | | | | | SDShypervisor | | storage | | | +--------------------------------------+ ```` Add a new volume driver in nova/virt/libvirt/volume.py file to realize attach/detach volume to qemu-kvm instance, and realize abstract volume dirver methods: * connect_volume * disconnect_volume Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- User will be able to attach Huawei SDSHypervisor volume to Nova instance. Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: zhangni <zhangni@huawei.com> Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- Realize new libvirt volume driver using CLI. Add unit test for Huawei SDShypervisor libvirt volume driver. Dependencies ============ Cinder can access Huawei SDSHypervisor to create volume/snapshot and so on. This has been merged to cinder in this review url https://review.openstack.org/#/c/101688/ Testing ======= Add unit test for Huawei SDShypervisor libvirt volume driver. Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Cinder/HuaweiSDSHypervisorDriver

commit_message:
Fix issues in User CRUD section

The user CRUD section had several issues.

 - CRUD wasn't defined
 - public_api is a literal string from the config file
 - The pipelines are now defined in keystone-paste.ini
 - The default pipeline has changed, stats_monitoring and xml_body
   don't exist anymore
 - tokens are invalidated in every token persistence backend

These are corrected.

Change-Id: I0620e8543d76220e2263ace2145e2b4eb0529b30
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/55/179655/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <para>Identity provides a user CRUD (Create, Read, Update, and Delete) filter that can be added to the <literal>public_api</literal> pipeline. The user CRUD filter enables users to use a HTTP PATCH to change their own password. To enable this extension you should define a <literal>user_crud_extension</literal> filter, insert it after <literal>public_service</literal> application in the <literal>public_api</literal> WSGI pipeline in <filename>keystone-paste.ini</filename>. For example:</para>pipeline = sizelimit url_normalize request_id build_auth_context token_auth admin_token_auth json_body ec2_extension user_crud_extension public_service</programlisting> tokens for the user are invalidated.</para>
deleted_lines: <para>Identity provides a user CRUD filter that can be added to the public_api pipeline. This user CRUD filter enables users to use a HTTP PATCH to change their own password. To enable this extension you should define a <literal>user_crud_extension</literal> filter, insert it after <literal>public_service</literal> application in the public_api WSGI pipeline in <filename>keystone.conf</filename>. For example:</para>pipeline = stats_monitoring url_normalize token_auth admin_token_auth xml_body json_body debug ec2_extension user_crud_extension public_service</programlisting> tokens for the user are deleted (if the back end is KVS or SQL).</para>
