Deprecations

bp deprecations

Change-Id: I2e99d6737ead312da208d228cce2b17464ec444c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone-specs refs/changes/81/153881/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============ Deprecations ============ `bp deprecations <https://blueprints.launchpad.net/python-keystoneclient/+spec/deprecations>`_ keystoneclient needs a consistent way to notify applications that deprecated behavior is being used. Problem Description =================== keystoneclient doesn't advertise deprecations consistently. All these techniques are used: * A comment in the code. * The Docstring mentions it. * Python's ``warnings`` module is used. * A FIXME comment that says to deprecate it When things are deprecated properly they're not really deprecated. A comment in the code isn't going to be visible to developers. Developers can't be expected to read the code to figure out what's deprecated. Proposed Change =============== keystoneclient will use a consistent way to advertise deprecations. The proposed way is to use Python's ``warnings`` module. When deprecated behavior is used, there will be a call like :: warnings.warn("description", KeystoneclientDeprecationWarning) A new class will be created ``KeystoneclientDeprecationWarning`` which will be used for all deprecations. This will give the developer control over how keystoneclient deprecations are handled. The existing deprecations, pending deprecations, etc., will be changed to use the consistent method. Alternatives ------------ oslo.log provides a deprecations log, but then keystoneclient would have to use oslo.log and I don't think that oslo.log is usable in libraries. Security Impact --------------- By deprecating things properly we'll be able to remove the code and have less code to maintain with potential security problems. Notifications Impact -------------------- None. Other End User Impact --------------------- Depending on how the application has configured ``warnings`` already, they may see the application fail, print errors, etc. Performance Impact ------------------ None. Other Deployer Impact --------------------- None. Developer Impact ---------------- Developers can use Python's ``warnings`` module normally, so they can cause deprecations to be ignored, or raise an exception, or log, or whatever. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: <blk-u> Brant Knudson Work Items ---------- * Create class KeystoneclientDeprecationWarning * Change existing uses of DeprecationWarning to use KeystoneclientDeprecationWarning. * Find places where comments or deprecations used to indicate deprecation and use the new KeystoneclientDeprecationWarning. * Find places where FIXME was used to indicate to deprecate something and use the new KeystoneclientDeprecationWarning. Dependencies ============ None. Documentation Impact ==================== The keystoneclient documentation will be changed to say that the library uses Python's ``warnings`` module for deprecations and that all deprecations in keystoneclient are based off the KeystoneclientDeprecationWarning class. References ========== * https://docs.python.org/2.6/library/warnings.html

commit_message:
Removed tempest git entry

The tempest role has an entry within the defaults of the role and
it could cause confusion when dealing with tempest as the main
package version is being specified in
`vars/repo_packages/openstack_services.yml`. Being that these
variables are no longer used they have been removed.

Implements blueprint: master-kilofication
(cherry picked from commit bddfa51fce403d84dd9a2ae9f9fa1baf7f582dbc)


Change-Id: I197afac1ce50d9bad778dda5cc4a23a0821fceeb

commit_message:
Revert state if attachment already exists

When attach is called twice for the same volume and instance the
attach_volume checks if the attachment already exists and returns.
This leaves the volume in 'Attaching' state. The volume status should
be reset to 'in-use' if we see the attachment already exists.

Change-Id: I2a2d28de59af234300082ab4655b0bc10699d54c
Closes-Bug: #1449980
(cherry picked from commit 709949d904c7f1d0e13b41bf6723d71bcf6b5652)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/07/179207/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Fix assert on call count for encodeutils.safe_decode mock
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-04-30 21:34:50.000000000', 'files': ['nova/tests/unit/virt/libvirt/test_driver.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/f0e06f0f58f9c5620b91684d3fdfd7b37cc7e7fb', 'message': "Fix assert on call count for encodeutils.safe_decode mock

Commit c084b9d57ce8def5a20159364c16290ad67ad0a5 added a global call to
encodeutils.safe_decode in oslo.log 1.1.0 which can mess up the strict
call_count check on the mock in this test.

This prevents nova from updating requirements.txt to use oslo.log >=
1.1.0 so we have to change the test to be less restrictive about the
mock call count here.

We just check the calls to the mock and make sure that at least two
calls were made where the errors='ignore' kwarg was passed, which is
what _create_domain does.

Change-Id: I68d41c2713ad558112c35e4a35af39a4ef3bdec6
"}]
commit_message:
Fix assert on call count for encodeutils.safe_decode mock

Commit c084b9d57ce8def5a20159364c16290ad67ad0a5 added a global call to
encodeutils.safe_decode in oslo.log 1.1.0 which can mess up the strict
call_count check on the mock in this test.

This prevents nova from updating requirements.txt to use oslo.log >=
1.1.0 so we have to change the test to be less restrictive about the
mock call count here.

We just check the calls to the mock and make sure that at least two
calls were made where the errors='ignore' kwarg was passed, which is
what _create_domain does.

Change-Id: I68d41c2713ad558112c35e4a35af39a4ef3bdec6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/54/179254/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # There is a global in oslo.log which calls encodeutils.safe_decode # which could be getting called from any number of places, so we need # to just assert that safe_decode was called at least twice in # _create_domain with the errors='ignore' kwarg. safe_decode_ignore_errors_calls = 0 for call in mock_safe_decode.call_args_list: # call is a tuple where 0 is positional args and 1 is a kwargs dict if call[1].get('errors') == 'ignore': safe_decode_ignore_errors_calls += 1 self.assertTrue(safe_decode_ignore_errors_calls >= 2, 'safe_decode should have been called at least twice')
deleted_lines: self.assertEqual(2, mock_safe_decode.call_count)

commit_message:
Drop use of 'oslo' namespace package

The Oslo libraries have moved all of their code out of the 'oslo'
namespace package into per-library packages. The namespace package was
retained during kilo for backwards compatibility, but will be removed by
the liberty-2 milestone. This change removes the use of the namespace
package, replacing it with the new package names.

The patches in the libraries will be put on hold until application
patches have landed, or L2, whichever comes first. At that point, new
versions of the libraries without namespace packages will be released as
a major version update.

Please merge this patch, or an equivalent, before L2 to avoid problems
with those library releases.

Blueprint: remove-namespace-packages
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/oslo-incubator/+spec/remove-namespace-packages

Change-Id: Ifa8baab33cdb3e606cf175a8c29c3a4ef6c44480

commit_message:
Update Backup and Restore section for NFS driver

Kilo adds support for use of an NFS exported backup repository
alongside Swift, Ceph, and TSM.

This update provides information in the Backup and Restore section
of the Cinder chapter of the Administrator's Guide on configuration
settings for the NFS backup driver.

Change-Id: I7754e640dd5d33e9c7afc664d4dbc5e4fddde7a7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/26/175826/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <para>By default, the Swift object store is used for the backup repository.</para> <para>If instead you want to use an NFS export as the backup repository, add the following configuration parameters to the <literal>[DEFAULT]</literal> section of the <filename>cinder.conf</filename> file and restart the Block Storage services: </para> <programlisting language="ini"> backup_driver=cinder.backup.drivers.nfs backup_share=<replaceable>HOST</replaceable>:<replaceable>EXPORT_PATH</replaceable> </programlisting> <para>For the <option>backup_share</option> parameter, replace <replaceable>HOST</replaceable> by the DNS resolvable host name or the IP address of the storage server for the NFS share, and <replaceable>EXPORT_PATH</replaceable> with the path to that share. If your environment requires that non-default mount options be specified for the share, set these as follows: </para> <programlisting language="ini"> backup_mount_options=<replaceable>MOUNT_OPTIONS</replaceable> </programlisting> <para>Here <replaceable>MOUNT_OPTIONS</replaceable> is a comma-separated string of NFS mount options as detailed in the NFS man page. </para> <para>There are several other parameters whose default values may be overriden as appropriate for your environment: </para> <programlisting language="ini"> backup_compression_algorithm=zlib backup_sha_block_size_bytes=32768 backup_file_size=1999994880 </programlisting> <para> <option>backup_compression_algorithm</option> may be set to <literal>bz2</literal> or <literal>None</literal>. The latter can be a useful setting when the server providing the share for the backend repository itself performs deduplication or compression on the backup data. </para> <para> <option>backup_file_size</option> must be a multiple of <option>backup_sha_block_size_bytes</option>. It is effectively the maximum file size to be used, given your environment, to hold backup data. Volumes larger than this will be stored in multiple files in the backup repository. <option>backup_sha_block_size_bytes</option> determines the size of blocks from the Cinder volume being backed up on which digital signatures are calculated in order to enable a future incremental backup capability. </para>

The InstanceInfoCache save method calls db.instance_info_cache_update
to update the database and receives an updated sqlalchemy model as a
return value. However, the result isn't saved to the self.fields of
the InstanceInfoCache object, though it is sent to update cells,
which is inconsistent. It doesn't seem critical as we expect to
receive mostly the same data back from the database as we already

Change-Id: I64be855a194990f898ce4e572f42975a07bf1d3c

commit_message:
Update self with db result in InstanceInfoCache.save

The InstanceInfoCache save method calls db.instance_info_cache_update
to update the database and receives an updated sqlalchemy model as a
return value. However, the result isn't saved to the self.fields of
the InstanceInfoCache object, though it is sent to update cells,
which is inconsistent. It doesn't seem critical as we expect to
receive mostly the same data back from the database as we already
have, except for the "created_at" and "updated_at" fields.

Change-Id: I64be855a194990f898ce4e572f42975a07bf1d3c

commit_message:
Decrease PO files for python projects

Remove untranslated strings and location information from PO files. The
location information is still in the POT files as reference for easy
regeneration using "msgmerge POTFILE POFILE -o COMPLETEPOFILE".

This moves the git add command to the end since compress_po_files
changes the files.

Change-Id: I8d9f80276085ffe4dd614960457637330ca28370
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/47/176947/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Compress downloaded po files, this needs to be done after # cleanup_po_files since that function needs to have information the # number of untranslated strings. compress_po_files "$PROJECT" # Now add all changed files to git. git add $PROJECT/locale/*
deleted_lines: # Add all changed files to git. git add $PROJECT/locale/*

subject: Always call hdisk removal from vscsi volume driver
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-05-01 12:39:08.000000000', 'files': ['nova_powervm/tests/virt/powervm/volume/test_vscsi.py', 'nova_powervm/virt/powervm/volume/vscsi.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova-powervm/commit/e7090a7169d4f7b9731a7cd1d20b0891202b8d21', 'message': 'Always call hdisk removal from vscsi volume driver

This change updates the vscsi volume driver to ensure that the hdisk
removal is always invoked.  The hdisk removal significantly speeds up
subsequent discoveries.  The changes to pypowervm should remove risks
from running the API.

The change is done so that an error from the hdisk job does not block
volume disconnect.  The volume will have already been disconnected from
the VM by the time the command is run.  If the hdisk remove fails for
some reason, a subsequent attach should clean it up (but can be slower
when it does so).

Change-Id: Ib823f793ec4b951111301286743c6bd243b863fe
'}]
commit_message:
Always call hdisk removal from vscsi volume driver

This change updates the vscsi volume driver to ensure that the hdisk
removal is always invoked.  The hdisk removal significantly speeds up
subsequent discoveries.  The changes to pypowervm should remove risks
from running the API.

The change is done so that an error from the hdisk job does not block
volume disconnect.  The volume will have already been disconnected from
the VM by the time the command is run.  If the hdisk remove fails for
some reason, a subsequent attach should clean it up (but can be slower
when it does so).

Change-Id: Ib823f793ec4b951111301286743c6bd243b863fe
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-powervm refs/changes/64/179364/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: try: # Attempt to remove the hDisk hdisk.remove_hdisk(adapter, CONF.host, device_name, vio_wrap.uuid) except Exception as e: # If there is a failure, log it, but don't stop the process msg = (_LW("There was an error removing the hdisk " "%(disk)s from the Virtual I/O Server.") % {'disk': device_name}) LOG.warn(msg) LOG.warn(e)
deleted_lines: CONF.register_opts([ cfg.BoolOpt('enable_hdisk_removal', default=False, help='Automatically allow the system to remove ' 'the associated hdisk when a volume is ' 'disconnected.')]) # TODO(IBM): New method coming to support remove hdisk if CONF.enable_hdisk_removal: hdisk.remove_hdisk(adapter, CONF.host, device_name, vio_wrap.uuid)

commit_message:
Fix pbr and it's version checks (unblock gates)

New version of pbr 0.11 was released and it checks
that version in setup.cfg is bigger then latest tag

To avoid future issues we will let pbr calulate version
instead of hardcode them in setup.cfg

Temporary disable coverage job to merge this patch

Partial-bug: #1450731

Change-Id: I0c00c231cea1a0506107133803406eb56694f690

commit_message:
remove XML middleware from default paste config

While this patch removes the xml_body middleware from the default paste
pipeline (thus failing against tempest tests which expect it), it
preserves support and functional test coverage for that middleware.

This is a softer step toward https://review.openstack.org/#/c/125738/

Change-Id: Ibd8020967ea89e6c8c8a55073e658f180faf1c00
Closes-Bug: 1384382
Closes-Bug: 1384789
Blueprint: removed-as-of-kilo

commit_message:
Publishers will eventually time out if consumer never reconnects

If a client dies after sending a request to the server, the server may
loop forever retrying to deliver the reply.

Added config rabbit_publish_timeout defaults to 0 sec, no timeout at all.

Change-Id: Id7fb72f88be675d17f47c958c32d1055f967b820

added_lines: from oslo.messaging._drivers import common as rpc_common class TestReplyTimeout(test_utils.BaseTestCase): def setUp(self): super(TestReplyTimeout, self).setUp() self.messaging_conf.transport_driver = 'rabbit' self.messaging_conf.in_memory = True def test_reply_timeout(self): transport = messaging.get_transport(self.conf) self.addCleanup(transport.cleanup) driver = transport._driver target = messaging.Target(topic='testtopic') listener = driver.listen(target) def send_and_wait_for_reply(): try: reply = driver.send(target, dict(ctxt=1), dict(send=1), wait_for_reply=True, timeout=0.1) except rpc_common.Timeout as e: # ok, I expect a Timeout on send return self.assertTrue(False, "should be killed before receiving a reply") # start the sender sender = threading.Thread(target=send_and_wait_for_reply) sender.start() # receive the message msg = listener.poll() self.assertIsNotNone(msg) # wait for sender to timeout and die sender.join(0.5) # hack Publisher.send to always fail so msg.reply times out def send_ioerror(self, msg, timeout=None): raise IOError() from oslo.messaging._drivers.impl_rabbit import Publisher old_send = Publisher.send Publisher.send = send_ioerror try: driver.conf.rabbit_publish_timeout = 0.1 self.assertRaises(rpc_common.Timeout, msg.reply, dict(reply=1)) finally: # restore publisher.send Publisher.send = old_send TestSendReceive.generate_scenarios()

commit_message:
Hyper-V: checks for existent Notes in list_instance_notes

If there are VMs with Notes = None, the Hyper-V Driver cannot
start, as it tries to iterate over None, which results in an
exception.

This commit adds a check if the Notes exist, before iterating over
them.

Closes-Bug: #1438638

Change-Id: Icebdc03d7249fdf903b94b2f61f4891f5c9d6e50

commit_message:
Change ZeroMQ driver underlying pattern to REQ/REP

https://blueprints.launchpad.net/oslo.messaging/+spec/zmq-req-rep

Current zmq driver implementation is built over PUSH/PULL PUB/SUB socket patterns.
These kind of sockets are straight-forward one way directed.
So, to organize some backward replies (as CALL method does) we need to support
two socket pipelines PUSH/PULL for sending messages and subscribe for reply over PUB/SUB.

I assume that was made because of those days ZeroMQ restrictions.
Now we have two-directions socket types like REQ/REP (Request-Reply).
There is also ROUTER/DEALER async version of REQ/REP.
I'd like to propose to use this pattern in zmq driver.
This will reduce a second socket pipeline and a lot of surrounding code.

Change-Id: I5692e9db94c123d818b6ed63af70054ab1848336
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-specs refs/changes/31/171131/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ================================================== Change ZeroMQ driver underlying pattern to REQ/REP ================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/oslo.messaging/+spec/zmq-req-rep This spec proposes to change ZeroMQ driver underlying pattern from PUSH/PULL + PUB/SUB to REQ/REP + ROUTER/DEALER which will simplify drivers implementation and improve its reliability. Problem description =================== Currently ZeroMQ driver actually implements request-reply pattern, but do it on top of more primitive and less reliable PUSH/PULL. The main lack is that PUSH/PULL have no backwards connection for replying to sender. We send message one way and forget. If we'd like to receive reply we need to establish one more connection. In current driver implementation it is done over PUB/SUB. It results in a need of serving for one more socket connection pipeline. More code to make things work. More probability of connection fails. The main reason to change to REQ/REP is that it do all things "out of the box". Proposed change =============== Current ZeroMQ driver implementation uses cross-service zmq_receiver daemon as a proxy to have a single TCP connection (port) per node. All messages come to the TCP connection and then are spreading between services via IPC. So we have three parts to connect: rpc_client (REQ) <=> (ROUTER) zmq_receiver (DEALER) <=> (REP) rpc_server That's enough for CALL method. The advantage of REQ/REP socket is that it implements state machine to manage requests/replies and sending request when socket is in "waiting for reply" state causes an exception. So it ideally matches CALL requirements which should block awaiting reply. But this is bad for CAST. Here we can substitute REQ with DEALER which is async equivalent for REQ. We don't need to wait for reply when we use DEALER, but we still can receive replies. We even don't need to ignore them, but use as acknowledge signal that CAST message is delivered successfully. We also have a possibility to track unacknowledged messages and report about them if needed. So on this step we can see that reliability of REQ/REP is higher than with PUSH/PULL. There is some magic needed with REQ envelope when work with DEALER, but that's not a problem and it's clearly described in zmq-guide. So a chain for CAST will look like the following: rpc_client (DEALER) <=> (ROUTER) zmq_receiver (DEALER) <=> (REP) rpc_server DEALER is also suits perfectly for CAST with fanout. Message chain remains the same. And also the same for notifier. The rule is simple: if we need to block waiting for request then we use REQ, otherwise DEALER for sending asynchronous requests. ROUTER is an async substitution for REP. Alternatives ------------ Provide alternative Request-Reply implementation of the driver and not change current PUSH/PULL implementation. Impact on Existing APIs ----------------------- None. Security impact --------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ Number of connections will be reduced so it may increase performance. Configuration Impact -------------------- None. Developer Impact ---------------- Less code for supporting replies. Testing Impact -------------- Unit tests will need some changes. Existing functional tests should cover this change. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: ozamiatin Milestones ---------- Target Milestone for completion: liberty-1 Work Items ---------- Depends on the decision to change the current driver or to implement the new one. Incubation ========== None. Adoption -------- None. Library ------- oslo.messaging. Anticipated API Stabilization ----------------------------- None. Documentation Impact ==================== None. Dependencies ============ None. References ========== .. note:: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode

commit_message:
Allow complex filtering with embedded dicts

Allow filtering of searchable data to be done with multiple levels
of dict data, rather than only simple types (string, int, etc).
Two tests are added for testing a dict within the filtering dict,
and a dict within a dict within the filtering dict (to test the
recursive aspect).

commit_message:
Refactor oslotest base class into fixtures

Change-Id: Icda200b7f1d17e9d5cde2a2438df9cfdca0b48a5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-specs refs/changes/88/158788/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ====================================== Refactor Test Base Class in oslotest ====================================== Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/oslo?searchtext=oslotest-refactor As a general policy we want to avoid requiring projects to use test base classes defined in libraries they do not control. Test fixtures are more composable, and easier to test themselves. Problem description =================== Copied from :doc:`/specs/policy/test-tools`: We originally created oslotest as a place to include the base class for all unit tests across all projects, to give the projects common behaviors in their test suites. Using a common base class is not always possible, however, when applications want to use their own base class and test fixture classes in ways that do not mix well. Multiple inheritance, in particular, is a problem because the order of setup and tear-down for test cases is harder to reason about. Proposed change =============== 1. Provide a fixture to change the ``maxDiff`` attribute of a test case, with a default of 10,000 as in BaseTestCase. 2. Provide a fixture to wrap :class:`fixtures.Timeout` using an environment variable to set the actual timeout, based on :py:meth:`BaseTestCase._set_timeout`. 3. Provide a fixture to mock stdout and stderr, based on :py:meth:`BaseTestCase._fake_output`. 4. Provide a fixture to wrap :class:`fixtures.FakeLogger` using an environment variable to set the actual timeout, based on :py:meth:`BaseTestCase._fake_logs`. 5. Provide a fixture to create a temporary file with content to replicate the features of :py:meth:`BaseTestCase.create_tempfiles`. We should use one fixture per file, and provide the full path to the resulting file as an attribute of the fixture. 6. Add :class:`DeprecationWarning` to :py:meth:`BaseTestCase.setUp`. Alternatives ------------ Leave Everything Alone ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Leaving :class:`BaseTestCase` alone risks making it completely obsolete as projects drop its use due to issues with multiple inheritance. Impact on Existing APIs ----------------------- The existing :class:`DeprecationWarning` will not be changed other than to add the deprecation warning, so all existing users will continue to be able to use it until they move to the new fixtures. Security impact --------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Configuration Impact -------------------- None Developer Impact ---------------- Developers will need to create or update their own test base classes to use the desired fixtures. Testing Impact -------------- We will need unit tests for the new fixtures. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Who is leading the writing of the code? Or is this a blueprint where you're throwing it out there to see who picks it up? If more than one person is working on the implementation, please designate the primary author and contact. Primary assignee: Doug Hellmann Other contributors: <launchpad-id or None> Milestones ---------- Target Milestone for completion: Liberty-2 Work Items ---------- See "Proposed change" above. Incubation ========== N/A Adoption -------- N/A Library ------- N/A Anticipated API Stabilization ----------------------------- N/A Documentation Impact ==================== Each change will require updates to the API documentation for oslotest. Dependencies ============ * :doc:`/specs/policy/test-tools` References ========== * :doc:`/specs/policy/test-tools` .. note:: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode

subject: Spawn RADVD only in the master HA router
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-04-08 11:01:59.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/9e6414496f0de40a70f5e966441c61991a877aa9', 'message': 'Spawn RADVD only in the master HA router

Currently radvd is spawned in all the HA routers irrespective of the
state of the router. This approach has the following issues.

1. While processing the internal router ports (i.e., qr-xxx), ha_router
   removes the LLA of the interface and adds it as a VIP to Keepalived conf.
   Radvd daemon is spawned after this operation in the router namespace
   (if the port is associated with any IPv6 subnets). Radvd notices that
   qr-xxx interface does not have the LLA, so does not transmit any Router
   Advts. In this state, VMs fail to acquire IPv6 addresses because of the
   missing RAs. Radvd does not recover even after keepalived configures the
   LLA of the interface. The only solution is to restart/reload radvd daemon.
   Currently keepalived-state-change monitor does not do any radvd related
   operations when a state transition happens. So we endup in this state
   forever.
2. For all the routers in Backup state, qr-xxx interface does not have LLA
   as it is managed by keepalived and configured only on the Master HA router.
   In such agents syslog is flooded with the messages [1] and this can cause
   loss of other useful info.
   [1] - resetting ipv6-allrouters membership on qr-2e373555-97

This patch implements the following.
1. If the router is already in the Master state, we configure the LLA as a VIP
   in keepalived conf but do not delete the LLA of the internal interface.
2. We spawn radvd only if the router is in the Master State.
3. Keepalived-state-change monitor takes care of enabling/disabling radvd upon
   state transitions.

Closes-Bug: #1440699
Change-Id: I351c71d058170265bbb8b56e1f7a3430bd8828d5

commit_message:
Spawn RADVD only in the master HA router

Currently radvd is spawned in all the HA routers irrespective of the
state of the router. This approach has the following issues.

1. While processing the internal router ports (i.e., qr-xxx), ha_router
   removes the LLA of the interface and adds it as a VIP to Keepalived conf.
   Radvd daemon is spawned after this operation in the router namespace
   (if the port is associated with any IPv6 subnets). Radvd notices that
   qr-xxx interface does not have the LLA, so does not transmit any Router
   Advts. In this state, VMs fail to acquire IPv6 addresses because of the
   missing RAs. Radvd does not recover even after keepalived configures the
   LLA of the interface. The only solution is to restart/reload radvd daemon.
   Currently keepalived-state-change monitor does not do any radvd related
   operations when a state transition happens. So we endup in this state
   forever.
2. For all the routers in Backup state, qr-xxx interface does not have LLA
   as it is managed by keepalived and configured only on the Master HA router.
   In such agents syslog is flooded with the messages [1] and this can cause
   loss of other useful info.
   [1] - resetting ipv6-allrouters membership on qr-2e373555-97

This patch implements the following.
1. If the router is already in the Master state, we configure the LLA as a VIP
   in keepalived conf but do not delete the LLA of the internal interface.
2. We spawn radvd only if the router is in the Master State.
3. Keepalived-state-change monitor takes care of enabling/disabling radvd upon
   state transitions.

Closes-Bug: #1440699
Change-Id: I351c71d058170265bbb8b56e1f7a3430bd8828d5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/70/171570/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self._update_metadata_proxy(ri, router_id, state) self._update_radvd_daemon(ri, state) self.state_change_notifier.queue_event((router_id, state)) def _update_metadata_proxy(self, ri, router_id, state): def _update_radvd_daemon(self, ri, state): # Radvd has to be spawned only on the Master HA Router. If there are # any state transitions, we enable/disable radvd accordingly. if state == 'master': ri.enable_radvd() else: ri.disable_radvd()

commit_message:
Update pyScss and django-pyscss

pyScss <1.3 has an ordering bug which results in @imports
being included in semi-random order. This breaks the ordering
of the CSS parts of bootstrap, which breaks some critical
elements of bootstrap.

Change-Id: I77d6f41fe7c9617298484969220f6fdfe82c3c36
Depends-On: Idec7ce039b57476ce20b7b678431459c2ca0bdbf

commit_message:
Added branch creation to yaql ACL

To comply with the new governance for libraries yaql has to define
stable branches.
This patch allows yaql-release team to create new stable branches and
yaql-milestone team to maintain them.

Change-Id: If15ab12ffabe035b676fb46dabe46531689244ab

commit_message:
neutron subnet-create requires args at the end

The network name must be next to the CIDR otherwise `neutron
subnet-create` gets confused.

Change-Id: Ie8b19d3824e5e25f80c61f0794595813c80b98da

commit_message:
devstack: Give example of custom ovs git repo.

Provide an example of how to configure a custom OVS git repo.  This is
useful at the moment as the latest patches to make OVN work are not
all merged, so you may want to test from a branch that has them
applied already.

Change-Id: Ic1cacbee2d05c0889d2cc10f0d96d0fa1f45d60e

commit_message:
devstack: Fix git repo name assumptions.

Some parts of the devstack plugin assumed the git repo would always be
ovs.git.  Make it figure that out from the git repo URL.

commit_message:
Use the active WWPNs for connections

The initial code was gathering all of the FC ports for certain
operations.  This could lead to very long delays as the inactive ports
would run operations, and would eventually time out.

This change will only return the active ports for the VIOSes, resulting
in faster operations when dealing with storage.

Change-Id: I5c10e8e91ef6936f6c6c44644de54db3b18a41d5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-powervm refs/changes/72/179172/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: """Returns the WWPNs of the FC adapters across all VIOSes on system.""" wwpn_list.extend(vios.get_pfc_wwpns())

commit_message:
Add notes about official sub-projects.

There was recently a thread on openstack-dev titled "A big tent home
for Neutron backend code."

The thread began here:

    http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-April/062310.html

and has roughly ended up here:

    http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-April/062853.html

This patch is an attempt to reflect the end of that thread with
updates to docs.

Any further discussion should just continue on openstack-dev to avoid
forking the discussion between openstack-dev and gerrit.

Change-Id: I48dbe8ac69e60fbfd5e5082844004aaf9fdce539
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/52/175952/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Neutron Drivers Core Reviewer Teams ----------------------------------- The plugin decomposition effort has led to having many drivers with code in separate repositories with their own core reviewer teams. For each one of these repositories in the following repository list, there is a core team associated with it: * `Neutron project team <http://governance.openstack.org/reference/projects/neutron.html>`_ These teams are also responsible for handling their own specs if they choose to use them. However, by choosing to be a part of the Neutron project, they submit to oversight and veto by the Neutron PTL if any issues arise.

commit_message:
Default Service Node Status to Disabled

At the PHL Operators meetup, the large deployments group concluded new compute
capacity should be disabled by default. The group cited production issues
where instance failures were caused by untested compute provisioning. Disabling
new services by default is safer and allows operators to fully test
new before releasing it for use.

blueprint disable-compute-default

Change-Id: I29d5b3cf55985cd007a86cc7c507bd589d1e0f0b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/37/175037/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =========================================== Default New Compute Node Status to Disabled =========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/disable-compute-default Operators prefer to explicitly enable new compute capacity. Without default disable, there is no way to ensure new builds land on tested compute capacity. Problem description =================== At the PHL Operators meetup, the large deployments group concluded new compute capacity should be disabled by default. The group cited production issues where instance failures were caused by untested compute provisioning. Disabling new compute capacity by default is safer and allows operators to fully test new capacity before releasing it for use. Use Cases ---------- Project Priority ----------------- None (yet) Proposed change =============== * Change the compute service status to disabled by default Posting to get preliminary feedback on the scope of this spec. Alternatives ------------ Disabling cell is not favorable because individual compute hosts go through a lifecycle (rekick, bootstrap). Disabling a cell does not work for operators not using cells and operators adding capacity to existing cells. Data model impact ----------------- The default value of the Services table's disabled column would change to True. Migrations might be needed for new records to receive this default. REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- Operators will have to explicitly enable new compute capacity. Developer impact ---------------- DevStack, etc. will have to be updated to enable the new compute service. Implementation ============== None Assignee(s) ----------- None Work Items ---------- None Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= None Documentation Impact ==================== Deployers/Operators documentation need to be noted to explicitly enable compute capacity. References ========== * https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/PHL-ops-large-deployments History ======= None

commit_message:
Correct case on RPMs in bindep fallback

Unfortunately yum is case-sensitive, so to avoid implementing
additional search-and-match logic in bindep we should just respect
this platform quirk.

Change-Id: I5d2e95ad908a493966fb4edfe1fd5c5653ac08a7

deleted_lines: xorg-x11-server-xvfb [platform:rpm]

commit_message:
Allow manila-release group to push tags to manila-ui

It looks like manila-release was left off the acl when this
file was added, and I believe this was an accident.

commit_message:
Bind manila-ui project changes to IRC channel openstack-manila

Project Manila has its IRC channel called "openstack-manila" where announced
all changed for related projects. But manila-ui is absent. So, add it.

Change-Id: I5ab29333dc1d77e3cbcb0a9e0582d1be39c54090

commit_message:
Reuse call to _get_project_endpoint_group in tests

This change creates a new function that has a more descriptive name and allows
for code reuse.

subject: Change ironic maintenance method to align with power method
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-04-29 20:23:28.000000000', 'files': ['shade/tests/unit/test_shade.py', 'shade/__init__.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/shade/commit/7468d1150c55c8cf277605d6e2cac22854751061', 'message': 'Change ironic maintenance method to align with power method

Upon obtaining a better understanding of the Ironicclient and Ironic
API interaction, along with what is actually returned, which should
be None, it makes sense to have set_machine_maintenance_state match
set_power_state in behavior.

Change-Id: I2899f290c0521e35d010dc9246b590ca9e949214
'}]
commit_message:
Change ironic maintenance method to align with power method

Upon obtaining a better understanding of the Ironicclient and Ironic
API interaction, along with what is actually returned, which should
be None, it makes sense to have set_machine_maintenance_state match
set_power_state in behavior.

Change-Id: I2899f290c0521e35d010dc9246b590ca9e949214
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/shade refs/changes/32/178832/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: :returns: None result = self.manager.submitTask( result = self.manager.submitTask( if result is not None: self.log.debug( "Failed setting machine maintenance state on node %s. " "User requested '%s'.' Received: %s" % ( name_or_id, state, result)) raise OpenStackCloudException( "Failed setting machine maintenance state on node %s. " "Received: %s" % (name_or_id, result)) return None :raises: OpenStackCloudException on operation error. :returns: None
deleted_lines: :returns: Per the API, no value should be returned with a successful operation. return self.manager.submitTask( return self.manager.submitTask( :returns: Dictonary object representing the updated node.

Change-Id: I4e1ce863d5a93d81ec90ae1c244cbfef68912916
'}]
commit_message:
Add Ironic machine power state pass-through

Adding machine power state passthrough in the form of
a _set_machine_power_state method, along with wrapper methods
set_machine_power_on, set_machine_power_off and
set_machine_power_reboot.

Tests to utilize the on, off, and reboot methods have been
which all invoke the _set_machine_power_state method.

Change-Id: I4e1ce863d5a93d81ec90ae1c244cbfef68912916

commit_message:
Change apache service to restart

After fixing the apache service issue with Ubuntu14.04, restart
command should work better that manual stop/start. While stopping
and starting a service using scripts, it can sometimes be too fast
to give time to the service to respond properly and cause error
status and more races.

Change-Id: I84b2271f07a10ce1a29403312736272221895c35
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/training-guides refs/changes/01/175901/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: sudo service apache2 stop sudo service apache2 start

added_lines: # -*- coding: utf-8 -*- # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """ test_compute ---------------------------------- Functional tests for `shade` image methods. """ import tempfile import uuid from shade import openstack_cloud from shade.tests import base from shade.tests.functional.util import pick_image class TestCompute(base.TestCase): def setUp(self): super(TestCompute, self).setUp() # Shell should have OS-* envvars from openrc, typically loaded by job self.cloud = openstack_cloud() self.image = pick_image(self.cloud.nova_client.images.list()) def test_create_image(self): test_image = tempfile.NamedTemporaryFile(delete=False) test_image.write('\0' * 1024 * 1024) test_image.close() image_name = 'test-image-%s' % uuid.uuid4() try: self.cloud.create_image(name=image_name, filename=test_image.name, disk_format='raw', container_format='bare', wait=True) finally: self.cloud.delete_image(image_name, wait=True)

commit_message:
Add minor OperatorCloud documentation

The documentation for the OperatorCloud methods with docstrings will not
be generated unless the class itself has a docstring. This adds a simple
docstring just to get the documentation generated.

Also adds a link to the CONTRIBUTING.rst doc pointing to the project
documentation.

Change-Id: I535289a938f68895c19b5e226d2e2302b566d00d

commit_message:
Allow for int or string ID comparisons

Some IDs are clearly strings (e.g., UUIDs) and some look like integers
(e.g., flavor ID of '100'). Let's make it easy for a user by allowing
for string or int. For example:

    flavor = cloud.get_flavor(100)

or

    flavor = cloud.get_flavor('100')

The former example using the int doesn't work, but this fixes that.

Change-Id: If201352a9917d7c8fba7b386b38fced9949f00a9

commit_message:
Basic infrastructure for HA Guide conversion to RST

The High Availability Guide is being rewritten and the team
has chosen to use RST.  This patch puts the infrastructure in
place.  Existing content will be improved and moved over, and
new content will be added here rather than the docbook.

The tox.ini file excludes this content from being published at
this time.

To generate the HA guide, use:  tox -e ha

Change-Id: If72e0b89ce1b561bce4439b4811256b620856954

commit_message:
Correct LICENSE tag.

Set LICENSE to MIT as per https://github.com/angular/angular.js/blob/master/LICENSE.

The license name is in the SPDX format (https://spdx.org/licenses/),
OSI approved, and thus Open https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Open

Bump build #.

Change-Id: I74558c0cd6a771bb83fefabbc14cd182d4fa0b45

commit_message:
Remove region_name from service catalog

This would allow you to save a region_name on the catalog so that all
your responses were relative to that region_name. This was deprecated,
if you want to search by region name you have to provide it.

Change-Id: Idd7a62a6ce44c3697f62939038d0322482f1e527
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystoneauth refs/changes/16/178916/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def factory(cls, resource_dict, token=None): return ServiceCatalogV3(token, resource_dict) elif ServiceCatalogV2.is_valid(resource_dict): return ServiceCatalogV2(resource_dict) def __init__(self, resource_dict): super(ServiceCatalogV2, self).__init__() def __init__(self, token, resource_dict): super(ServiceCatalogV3, self).__init__()
deleted_lines: def factory(cls, resource_dict, token=None, region_name=None): return ServiceCatalogV3(token, resource_dict, region_name) elif ServiceCatalogV2.is_valid(resource_dict): return ServiceCatalogV2(resource_dict, region_name) def __init__(self, region_name=None): self._region_name = region_name @property def region_name(self): # FIXME(jamielennox): Having region_name set on the service catalog # directly is deprecated. It should instead be provided as a parameter # to calls made to the service_catalog. Provide appropriate warning. return self._region_name region_name = region_name or self._region_name def __init__(self, resource_dict, region_name=None): super(ServiceCatalogV2, self).__init__(region_name=region_name) def __init__(self, token, resource_dict, region_name=None): super(ServiceCatalogV3, self).__init__(region_name=region_name)

commit_message:
Remove the AccessInfo Factory

Replace it with a create that is much simpler.

I did this as a standalone method rather than a classmethod as I don't
think it really applies to the current class.

Change-Id: I3dad2359e1956ddbb16486445fe6c04814d50fa0

commit_message:
Remove region_name from catalog

This was used to affect the urls that were returned from the catalog.
This should never have been here and is deprecated.

Change-Id: I320e3801ba045f4608baef246e9a48fa4c743421

Remove auth_url property from AccessInfo

deleted_lines: def auth_url(self): """Returns a tuple of URLs from publicURL and adminURL for the service 'identity' from the service catalog associated with the authorization request. If the authentication request wasn't scoped to a tenant (project), this property will return None. DEPRECATED: this doesn't correctly handle region name. You should fetch it from the service catalog yourself. :returns: tuple of urls """ raise NotImplementedError() @property def auth_url(self): # FIXME(jamielennox): this is deprecated in favour of retrieving it # from the service catalog. Provide a warning. if self.service_catalog: return self.service_catalog.get_urls(service_type='identity', endpoint_type='publicURL', region_name=self._region_name) else: return None @property def auth_url(self): # FIXME(jamielennox): this is deprecated in favour of retrieving it # from the service catalog. Provide a warning. if self.service_catalog: return self.service_catalog.get_urls(service_type='identity', endpoint_type='public', region_name=self._region_name) else: return None @property

Added "Alternatives" and a couple editorial mods

Also added requirement to the Intersphinx tools for cross-referencing
docs in other repos.

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/docs-specs refs/changes/71/178871/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: This guide provides Openstack cloud operators with configuration details and best practices guidelines for creating a highly-available cloud environment. the various best practices for creating a highly-available cloud. This restructure will offer readers a more logical flow between an initial installation and adopting high availability components for an OpenStack#. We assume that users have already built at least a "learning" OpenStack#. The HA Guide should be structured to parallel the Install Guide as much - HA Intro and Concepts - Hardware setup - Infrastructure prerequisites that we assume are in place before starting an HA deployment or upgrade - HA networking -- Neutron only (very high-level with handoff to Networking Guide) - HA configuration for Controller services - HA configuration for Storage services, including brief discussion of the advantages of Ceph and a handoff to Ceph documentation for configuration details - HA configuration for Compute node services - Other HA configuration (Ceilometer/MongoDB, Heat, Trove) #. The HA Guide should heavily reference the Install Guide and will then#. Similarly, we expect that the Networking Guide will handle#. The HA Guide should emphasize a reasonable, standard deployment based on#. In general, the HA Guide should only cover core OpenStack services.#. The HA guide should cover all appropriate Linux distros/platforms. #. We will reuse as much of the material in the existing HA Guide as#. Some attempt will be made to incorporate material for both the Juno andcurrently assigned. The guide should be re-written with the assumptions outlined- Maintain the current structure, splitting between active/active and active/passive. This puts the onus on the user to figure out what to do in what order. - Fully incorporate HA configuration information into the Install Guides. This would really complicate the process of creating and maintaining the Install Guides and would defeat the goal of having the Install Guides be easy to follow for people who are new to OpenStack and may also be new to Linux. - Create a comprehensive HA Install Guide that replicates relevant information from the Install Guides. This would create a maintenance nightmare. - Relegate all HA configuration information to the documentation for the individual components. This would make it very difficult for the user to get the "big picture" about how to implement HA for an environment. While we plan to have the details of HA for networking and many non-core services covered in the documentation for those pieces, we need a single document that details the process of getting the major Controller services configured for HA and provides a roadmap for all HA configuration.
deleted_lines: In order to "win the enterprise" OpenStack cloud operators need to understand the various best practices for creating a highly-available cloud. We think this restructure will offer readers a more logical flow between an initial install and adopting high availability components for an OpenStack1. We assume that users have already built at least a "learning" OpenStack2. The HA Guide should be structured to parallel the Install Guide as much- HA Intro and Concepts - Hardware setup - Infrastructure prerequisites that we assume are in place before starting an HA deployment or upgrade - HA networking -- Neutron only (very high-level with handoff to Networking Guide) - HA configuration for Controller services - HA configuration for Storage services, including brief discussion of the advantages of Ceph and a handoff to Ceph documentation for configuration details - HA configuration for Compute node services - Other HA configuration (Ceilometer/MongoDB, Heat, Trove) 3. The HA Guide should heavily reference the Install Guide and will then4. Similarly, we expect that the Networking Guide will handle5. The HA Guide should emphasize a reasonable, standard deployment based on6. In general, the HA Guide should only cover core OpenStack services.7. The HA guide should cover all appropriate Linux distros/platforms. 8. We will reuse as much of the material in the existing HA Guide as9. Some attempt will be made to incorporate material for both the Juno andcurrently assigned. he guide should be re-written with the assumptions outlinedWhat other ways could we do this document? Why aren't we using those? This doesn't have to be a full literature review, but it should demonstrate that thought has been put into why the proposed solution is an appropriate one.

commit_message:
Adds config files to Install and configure storage nodes

Configuration files for container-reconciler and object-expirer
 are not provided during the swift install. This commit adds
 them to the install and configure storage node components section.

Change-Id: Iccc33509f0917652c686e9e0f1baa23cbde2f7bc
Closes-Bug: #1437185

commit_message:
Add checking for name during plugin creation

Currently plugin builder can verify correctness only
after plugin was created. It gives to user possibility
creates plugin with incorrect name. This fix provides
validation for name on creation stage.

Change-Id: Ib54313fac6b246288838e48ce483046e47a5a7bb
Closes-Bug: #1439760

commit_message:
Use the AccessInfoPlugin from keystoneclient

The AccessInfoPlugin that is mentioned in the comments is now available
from keystoneclient. We should use that instead of our own copy.

commit_message:
Dell SC driver calls out the wrong REST API version

On initialization of the session with the Dell REST
API the dell api version was incorrectly specified.
It should be 2.0 rather than 1.5.

Change-Id: I47ef63c24305b23125802012aa3c9dfde76813fd
Closes-Bug: #1446868
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/95/176095/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.header['x-dell-api-version'] = '2.0'
deleted_lines: self.header['x-dell-api-version'] = '1.5'

commit_message:
Plan for first iteration of CI gate infrastructure

This outlines some preliminary thoughts on upstream CI testing
for Akanda projects.

Implements blueprint ci-updates

Change-Id: I64b4d0b9f34e6e00b7ba6abcfdc1dd9408c3d13b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack-attic/akanda refs/changes/10/178010/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode Title of your blueprint ======================= Akanda CI updates for Kilo Problem Description =================== We build lots of interconnected things but dont test any of the things. We should be employing pre-commit testing similar to other projects to ensure users get something thats not broken when deploying from master of git repositories or generated tarballs and images. Proposed Change =============== All changes to Akanda projects should go through regular check and gate phases that test a deployment containing proposed code changes. This includes changes to Akanda code as well as supporting things like its devstack code and ``akanda-appliance-builder``. We can leverage devstack, tempest and diskimage-builder to do this and create a generic Akanda integration testing job that can be added to the pipelines of relevant projects. We should also be running standard unit test coverage and pep8 checks here, too. For code that runs in the Akanda appliance VM or code that is used to build said image, we should ensure that tests run against proposed changes and not static, pre-built appliance images. That is, runs that are testing changes to ``akanda-appliance`` should build and entirely new appliance VM image and use that for its integration tests instead of pulling a pre-built image that does not contain the code under review. Additionally, we should be archiving the results of changes to these appliance-related repositories as a 'latest' image. That is, if someone lands a change to ``akanda-appliance``, we should build and archive a VM image in a known location on the internet. This will speed up other tests that do not need to build a new image but should run against the latest version, and also avoid forcing users to needlessly build images. For changes that do not modify the appliance code or tooling used to build the image, tests should run with a pre-built image. This can be either a 'latest' image or a released, versioned image. Data Model Impact ----------------- None REST API Impact --------------- None Security Impact --------------- None Notifications Impact -------------------- None Other End User Impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other Deployer Impact --------------------- None Developer Impact ---------------- Developers hoping to land code in any of the Akanda repositories will need to ensure their code passes all gate tests before it can land. Community Impact ---------------- This may make landing changes a bit slower but should improve the overall quality and health of Akanda repositories. Alternatives ------------ Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Work Items ---------- * Enable pep8 and unit test jobs against relevant Akanda repositories. * Move existing devstack code to out of ``http://github.com/dreamhost/akanda-devstack.git`` and into a proper gerrit-managed Akanda repository in the stackforge namespace. * Complete diskimage-builder support that currently exists in ``http://github.com/stackforge/akanda-appliance-builder.git`` * Update devstack code to either pull a pre-built Akanda appliance image from a known URL or to build one from source for use in test run. * Create a generic ``(check|gate)-dsvm-tempest-akanda`` job that spins up the Akanda devstack deployment and runs a subset of Tempest tests against it. * Identifiy the subset of Tempest tests we care to run. * Run the devstack job against changes to ``akanda-appliance`` or ``akanda-appliace-builder`` with a configuration such that the appliance image will be built from source including the patch under review. * Setup infrastructure to publish a new appliance image (ie, akanda-appliance-latest.qcow2) to a known location on the internet after code lands in ``akanda-appliance`` or ``akanda-appliance-builder`` * Run the devstack job against all other relevant akanda repositories with a configuration such that a pre-built appliance image from a known location on the internet. Ideally, this will be the image produced from changes to the appliance repositories (ie, akanda-appliance-latest.qcow2) Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Tempest Tests ------------- n/a Functional Tests ---------------- n/a API Tests --------- n/a Documentation Impact ==================== User Documentation ------------------ Should be updated to reflect the new home of devstack code and proper ways to deploy it. Developer Documentation ----------------------- Should be updated to reflect the new home of devstack code and proper ways to deploy it. References ========== None

commit_message:
Context: is_admin==True implies is_advsvc=True

With this change is the is_admin parameter is set to True when
creating a context, the is_advsvc property is set to True as well,
without executing a pointless check with policy engine.

Closes-Bug: #1450244

Change-Id: I0a21a82692665599260d07c00c55df18fc926eb5

deleted_lines: self.is_advsvc = policy.check_is_advsvc(self)

Provide a warning. if self.service_catalog: return self.service_catalog.get_urls(service_type='identity', endpoint_type='adminURL', region_name=self._region_name) else: return None @property def management_url(self): # FIXME(jamielennox): this is deprecated in favour of retrieving it # from the service catalog. Retain chain of missing dependencies

Change-Id: I170bedb5c667aa30764ad29634910dda40c6cd49
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/48/176148/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Attempt to retain a chain of what was missing (so that the final # raised exception for the flow has the nodes that had missing # dependencies). last_cause = None local_missing = fetch(node.name, node.rebind, optional_args=node.optional) if local_missing: cause = exc.MissingDependencies(node, sorted(local_missing), cause=last_cause) last_cause = cause missing.update(local_missing) if missing: raise exc.MissingDependencies(self._flow, sorted(missing), cause=last_cause)
deleted_lines: missing.update(fetch(node.name, node.rebind, optional_args=node.optional)) if missing: raise exc.MissingDependencies(self._flow, sorted(missing))

deleted_lines: import getpass import hashlibimport sys from oslo_utils import encodeutils import prettytable import six from keystoneauth import exceptions# Decorator for cli-args def arg(*args, **kwargs): def _decorator(func): # Because of the semantics of decorator composition if we just append # to the options list positional options will appear to be backwards. func.__dict__.setdefault('arguments', []).insert(0, (args, kwargs)) return func return _decorator def pretty_choice_list(l): return ', '.join("'%s'" % i for i in l) def print_list(objs, fields, formatters={}, order_by=None): pt = prettytable.PrettyTable([f for f in fields], caching=False, print_empty=False) pt.aligns = ['l' for f in fields] for o in objs: row = [] for field in fields: if field in formatters: row.append(formatters[field](o)) else: field_name = field.lower().replace(' ', '_') data = getattr(o, field_name, '') if data is None: data = '' row.append(data) pt.add_row(row) if order_by is None: order_by = fields[0] encoded = encodeutils.safe_encode(pt.get_string(sortby=order_by)) if six.PY3: encoded = encoded.decode() print(encoded) def _word_wrap(string, max_length=0): """wrap long strings to be no longer than max_length.""" if max_length <= 0: return string return '\n'.join([string[i:i + max_length] for i in range(0, len(string), max_length)]) def print_dict(d, wrap=0): """pretty table prints dictionaries. Wrap values to max_length wrap if wrap>0 """ pt = prettytable.PrettyTable(['Property', 'Value'], caching=False, print_empty=False) pt.aligns = ['l', 'l'] for (prop, value) in six.iteritems(d): if value is None: value = '' value = _word_wrap(value, max_length=wrap) pt.add_row([prop, value]) encoded = encodeutils.safe_encode(pt.get_string(sortby='Property')) if six.PY3: encoded = encoded.decode() print(encoded) def find_resource(manager, name_or_id): """Helper for the _find_* methods.""" # first try the entity as a string try: return manager.get(name_or_id) except (exceptions.NotFound): pass # finally try to find entity by name try: if isinstance(name_or_id, six.binary_type): name_or_id = name_or_id.decode('utf-8', 'strict') return manager.find(name=name_or_id) except exceptions.NotFound: msg = ("No %s with a name or ID of '%s' exists." % (manager.resource_class.__name__.lower(), name_or_id)) raise exceptions.CommandError(msg) except exceptions.NoUniqueMatch: msg = ("Multiple %s matches found for '%s', use an ID to be more" " specific." % (manager.resource_class.__name__.lower(), name_or_id)) raise exceptions.CommandError(msg) def unauthenticated(f): """Adds 'unauthenticated' attribute to decorated function. Usage:: @unauthenticated def mymethod(f): ... """ f.unauthenticated = True return f def isunauthenticated(f): """Checks to see if the function is marked as not requiring authentication with the @unauthenticated decorator. Returns True if decorator is set to True, False otherwise. """ return getattr(f, 'unauthenticated', False) def hash_signed_token(signed_text, mode='md5'): hash_ = hashlib.new(mode) hash_.update(signed_text) return hash_.hexdigest() def prompt_for_password(): """Prompt user for password if not provided so the password doesn't show up in the bash history. """ if not (hasattr(sys.stdin, 'isatty') and sys.stdin.isatty()): # nothing to do return while True: try: new_passwd = getpass.getpass('New Password: ') rep_passwd = getpass.getpass('Repeat New Password: ') if new_passwd == rep_passwd: return new_passwd except EOFError: return

commit_message:
Add min_size and max_size properties to Cluster

This patch added min_size and max_size properties to Cluster. Now
before cluster creating and updating, size related validation will
be done by comparing min_size/max_size/desired_capacity.

TODO:
  - Do size validation before node adding/deleting/migrating
  - Do size validation before cluster scaling
  - Heat stack update need support from SDK

Change-Id: Ibf792f5152f7bd5ada53ec7755bbe92616dbdcd5
Implements: blueprint add-size-limitation-properties-to-cluster

commit_message:
A sample spec complex scaling policy

We are supporting complex scaling policies that allow users to specify
conditions for each policy. I'm not sure if we should make this a
generic case for all.

commit_message:
Adding "requires" to "task-defaults" clause

* Reverse workflows can now use "requires" declared in
  "task-defaults", for example, to have all tasks
  depending on a configured task (except this task itself)
* Fixed a bug with "processed" flag, it shouldn't be taken
  into account for reverse workflows because if say task3
  depends on task2 then these tasks can't depend on a task1
  at the same time

Change-Id: Iad113e405f43125b37d16b91fcf448c21cd354e6
(cherry picked from commit fa0102354b6fd5f865fc33eb2f703f658bfe98b1)

commit_message:
Adding "requires" to "task-defaults" clause

* Reverse workflows can now use "requires" declared in
  "task-defaults", for example, to have all tasks
  depending on a configured task (except this task itself)
* Fixed a bug with "processed" flag, it shouldn't be taken
  into account for reverse workflows because if say task3
  depends on task2 then these tasks can't depend on a task1
  at the same time

Change-Id: Iad113e405f43125b37d16b91fcf448c21cd354e6

commit_message:
Fix binding:host_id for neutron on evacuate

Currently when doing an evacuate the neutron host_id binding for
the port isn't updated.

Currently in rebuild_instance() we call
self.network_api.setup_networks_on_host() but this doesn't actually
do anything for neutron.

For neutron the cleanest fix would be to change rebuild_instance()
to call self.network_api.setup_instance_network_on_host() but this
might break nova-network.

So as a test we're going to modify neutron's
setup_networks_on_host() to act the same as
setup_instance_network_on_host().  Hopefully this won't cause
problems elsewhere.

Change-Id: I5e420075400afbe064231be38f06438f48dd1178
Closes-Bug: #1444171
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/15/173615/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if not teardown: # This is only needed for the evacuate case, where # rebuild_instance() calls this routine and doesn't call # setup_instance_network_on_host() or migrate_instance_finish(). # If we get rid of nova-network we could remove this and change # rebuild_instance() to call setup_instance_network_on_host() # instead. self._update_port_binding_for_instance(context, instance, host)

commit_message:
Update trove config database connection

In Kilo, the sql_connection parameter was deprecated for trove.
This patch moves the sql connection to the [database] section.

Change-Id: Ic6391a14cf4cc4e8015ce3132502105b04874eba
Closes-Bug: 1434943

commit_message:
Compatibility fix for pyscss 1.3.4

This commit alters the action-list.scss file so it is compatible
with the newer version of pyScss (1.3.4+), allowing us to
upgrade to that version.

This change is a prerequisite for the update to get into the
global requirements so that that change can pass testing.

Change-Id: Idec7ce039b57476ce20b7b678431459c2ca0bdbf
Co-Authored-By: Kelly Domico <kelly.domico@hp.com>

commit_message:
Rename _discover module

_discover was private in keystoneclient because there was a circular
dependency. All the functions within have always been public as they
were imported into the keystoneclient.discover file.

Rename now we don't have to worry about our imports.

Change-Id: I4b6afcefd1376f8d2d0a8d2f602f967a1febf3f1

commit_message:
Remove Debug Traces from _output_hosts_file

On the stable/juno branch, bug #1414218 should have been fixed
by https://review.openstack.org/#/c/164329 (merged April 1st).
This patch removed LOG.debug statement from for-loop of method
_output_hosts_file(). However patch
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/153181 (also merged April 1st)
added LOG.debug statements to the for-loop of the same method.
The result is bug 1414218 isn't fixed on the stable/juno branch.
In order to have bug 1414218 fixed on the stable/juno branch the
LOG.debug statements in the for-loop of _output_hosts_file is
removed.

Change-Id: I7e620443d9835b65d276c1aed055cffc3bf4f13b
related-bug: #1414218
closes-bug: #1445202

commit_message:
Prevent false positives of UPDATE_COMPLETE in integration tests

Use the updated_at field in the stack output to check for
false positives of UPDATE_COMPLETE.

Partially-Closes Bug: #1433340

Change-Id: I8e68a2764741cc19305a0db7825322807b6508f3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/45/173045/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.updated_time = None # Handle special UPDATE_COMPLETE case. if status == 'UPDATE_COMPLETE': # Make sure we wait for the latest update # run to finish. # NOTE(sirushtim): If one somehow calls this function # twice without a stack-update call in between, we'd # be stuck in a loop waiting for a new updated_time. if self.updated_time != stack.updated_time: self.updated_time = stack.updated_time return else: return # Make sure it is not the failure of a previous run. wait_for_action = status.split('_')[0] curr_action = stack.stack_status.split('_')[0] if (curr_action == wait_for_action and fail_regexp.search(stack.stack_status)):
deleted_lines: return if fail_regexp.search(stack.stack_status):

commit_message:
Add timeout hidden parameter to AWS LB

Current implemenatation contains WaitCondition resource with timeout
equal 600. It is enough for fast hardware, unortunatelly thre are some
situation when need more time for downloading and installation all
related packages. As good example can be used our Heat gate job,
where provisioning one vm take more then 10 minutes.
This patch add paramater for WaitCondition timeout. Now it can be used
to change wait time for provisioning instance with all necessary packages.

Change-Id: Id80b2655f7e218cf884b86838d28588b865a5e56
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/20/177120/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: "Timeout" : "600"

commit_message:
Enable SecurityGroups property for AWS LB resource

AWS LB has SecurityGroups property, but it's not implemented.
This patch adds turn on this option by using SecurityGroups in nested
template as parameter and property for AWS::EC2::Instance.

Change-Id: I922cc97291179c79d1451a38cbb9e16933d703ef
Closes-Bug: #1443947

commit_message:
Support for ISO images in OpenStack Configuration Reference is incorrect

The instructions for how to build instances with ISO images is
incorrect in config-reference/iso-support. Following the original
instruction, users are unable to create functional instances, they
will stuck at system installation and rebooting.

This patch addes instructions about how to use ISO images to create
functional VMs without any third party softwares (just OpenStack).

Change-Id: I6c03cb8f7a6e5ca5a30a4f78b26965c47b7c397a
Closes-Bug:#1448894
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/91/177691/12 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --disk-format iso < ubuntu-14.04-server-amd64.iso</userinput></screen> <literal>ubuntu-14.04-server-amd64.iso</literal> <para>OpenStack supports booting VMs using ISO images, but in order to make the VMs created using ISO images, users need to do a few more steps:</para> <para>Firstly, boot VM(with ISO image) using the following command:</para> <screen><prompt>$</prompt> <userinput>nova boot --image ubuntu-14.04-server-amd64.iso \ --block-device source=blank,dest=volume,size=10,shutdown=preserve \ --nic net-id=<literal>network-id</literal> --flavor 3 instance_name</userinput></screen> <para>In this command, <literal>ubuntu-14.04-server-amd64.iso</literal> is the name of the new instance.<literal>network-id</literal>is a valid network id in your system</para> <para>PS. Block storage service is needed and the parameter <literal>shutdown=preserve</literal> is also mandatory.</para> <para>After the VM has been successfully launched, connect to the VM using VNC and follow the instructions to install the system as using ISO images on regular computers.</para> <para>When the installation is finished and system rebooted, you will find that the system will again ask you to install the system.</para> <para>Now you have to do the following actions to make your VMs created using ISO actually functional:</para> <para>Firstly, you have to delete the VM you just created:</para> <screen><prompt>$</prompt> <userinput>nova delete <literal>instance-name</literal></userinput></screen> <para>Now, your newly created VM has been deleted but the system you just installed using your ISO image remains since the parameter <literal>shutdown=preserve</literal> was set, run the following command:</para> <screen><prompt>$</prompt> <userinput>cinder list</userinput></screen> <para>You will get a list with all the volumes in your system. Among which, you can find the volume that was attached to your ISO created VM, with the "false" bootable property.</para> <para>Upload the volume to glance:</para> <screen><prompt>$</prompt> <userinput>cinder upload-to-image <literal>volume-uuid image-name</literal></userinput></screen> <para>the volume-uuid is the uuid of the volume that was attached to your ISO created VM and the image-name is the name that you want to name your new image.</para> <para>After the image was successfully uploaded, you can now use the new image to boot VMs, the VMs launched using this image will contain the system you just installed using the ISO image</para>
deleted_lines: --disk-format iso < ubuntu-13.04-server-amd64.iso</userinput></screen> <literal>ubuntu-13.04-server-amd64.iso</literal> <para>Run this command:</para> <screen><prompt>$</prompt> <userinput>nova boot --image ubuntu.iso \ --flavor 1 instance_name</userinput></screen> <para>In this command, <literal>ubuntu.iso</literal> is the name of the new instance.</para>

commit_message:
Text updates to firstapp tutorial

-Updated wording for clarity.
-Updated section description links to be consistent
in each section of the tutorial.

Change-Id: I59a0d4cabc653f8c52e15d504059ba7905f7857f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/api-site refs/changes/84/178284/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. todo:: provide delete instance command or link to section1 image files in a database is not good practice. We're doing itFrom here, you should go to :doc:`/section3` to learn how to scale your application further. Alternatively, you may jump to any of these* :doc:`/section4`: Learn how to use Object Storage to make your application more durable * :doc:`/section5`: Migrate the database to block storage, or use the database-as-a-service component * :doc:`/section6`: Automatically orchestrate the application * :doc:`/section7`: Learn about more complex networking * :doc:`/section8`: Get advice about operations * :doc:`/section9`: Learn some crazy things that you might not think to do ;) Complete code sample ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ The following file contains all of the code snippets from this section of the tutorial. This comprehensive code sample lets you install and run the code as a single program. Before you run this program, confirm that you have set your authentication information, the flavor ID, and image ID.
deleted_lines: image files in database is not good practice. We're doing itFrom here, you should go to :doc:`/section3` to learn how to scale the application further. Alternately, you may jump to any of these* :doc:`/section4`: to learn how to make your application more durable using Object Storage * :doc:`/section5`: to migrate the database to block storage, or use the database-as-as-service component * :doc:`/section6`: to automatically orchestrate the application * :doc:`/section7`: to learn about more complex networking * :doc:`/section8`: for advice for developers new to operations Full example code ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Here's every code snippet into a single file, in case you want to run it all in one, or you are so experienced you don't need instruction ;) If you are going to use this, don't forget to set your authentication information and the flavor and image ID.

commit_message:
Deprecate auth_token authentication

Applications should be using the standard authentication plugins
rather than auth_token authentication.

Change-Id: I1d7ef8267f353e2ea4af47352b3faa399afb11aa

added_lines: # pre-diablo only had project ID, which was also the Name project def assert_unscoped_default_project_auto_scopes(self, token): """Unscoped v2 requests with a default project should "auto-scope." The implied scope is the user's project ID. def test_default_project_uuid_token(self): self.assert_unscoped_default_project_auto_scopes( def test_default_project_signed_token(self): self.assert_unscoped_default_project_auto_scopes( """Unscoped requests with no default project ID should be rejected.""" auto-scope it (and fail if there is no default project)
deleted_lines: # pre-diablo only had Tenant ID, which was also the Name tenant def assert_unscoped_default_tenant_auto_scopes(self, token): """Unscoped v2 requests with a default tenant should "auto-scope." The implied scope is the user's tenant ID. def test_default_tenant_uuid_token(self): self.assert_unscoped_default_tenant_auto_scopes( def test_default_tenant_signed_token(self): self.assert_unscoped_default_tenant_auto_scopes( """Unscoped requests with no default tenant ID should be rejected.""" auto-scope it (and fail if there is no default tenant)

commit_message:
Update the TOSCA monitoring use case

Update the template with remaining components including elasticsearch,
logstash, kibana, rsyslog, collectd and nodejs samplea application. These
templates has been discussed and reviewed by TOSCA TC.

Change-Id: Ie842c288cbb2bd2d81e50c85b8b417ad7c5716dc
